Interactive Turing Machine

ğŸ“–Definition 44 (interactive Turing machine). An interactive TM MMM is a probabilistic TM equipped also with a write-only query tape and a read-only answer tape, and has two new special states, a query state and a continue state. The symbols allowed on the query and answer tape are given by a communication alphabet Î›\LambdaÎ›.

When MMM enters the query state, the contents mmm of the query tape as a message mmm sent by MMM. We say that we send a reply rrr to mmm by performing the following steps: The query tape is reinitialized to a blank tape, the string rrr is placed on the answer tape, and computation of MMM is resumed in the continue state.

Given two interactive TM, consider running both TM on the same input xxx and relaying messages back and forth. In this way we define interactive proof systems having one TM be the verifier VVV, assumed to be Polynomial-time bounded, and the other TM to be the prover PPP, just assume that PPP will always produce a reply to any message received.

P:Î›âˆ—â†’Î›âˆ—P:\Lambda^*\to\Lambda^*P:Î›âˆ—â†’Î›âˆ—

Given also a polynomial time interactive TM VVV, denote by (V,P)(x)(V,P)(x)(V,P)(x) the computation of VVV on input xxx where the replies to messages of VVV are determined as follows.

Suppose that VVV enters query states and m1,â‹¯â€‰,mim_1,\cdots,m_im1â€‹,â‹¯,miâ€‹ is the list of all messages sent by VVV. The reply given to the message mim_imiâ€‹ is P(âŸ¨x,m1,â‹¯â€‰,miâŸ©)P(\langle x,m_1,\cdots,m_i\rangle)P(âŸ¨x,m1â€‹,â‹¯,miâ€‹âŸ©).

ğŸ“–Definition 45 (interactive proof system). Let vvv be a polynomial time interactive Turing machine VVV, P:Î›âˆ—â†’Î›âˆ—P:\Lambda^*\to\Lambda^*P:Î›âˆ—â†’Î›âˆ—, and let 0â‰¤s<câ‰¤10\le s\lt c\le10â‰¤s<câ‰¤1. We say that the pair (V,P)(V,P)(V,P) is an interactive proof system for LLL with completeness ccc and soundness error sss if:

x\in L\Rarr\Pr[(V,P)(x)=yes]\ge c\\\and\\x\not\in L\Rarr\Pr[(V,\hat P)(x)=yes]\le s\forall \hat P

Define IPIPIP as the class of all languages that has an interactive proof system with completeness 3/43/43/4 and soundness error 1/41/41/4. We say that VVV is the verifier and PPP the prover of the interactive proof system (V,P)(V,P)(V,P).

We can view NPNPNP as a proof system without randomness or interaction other than a single message.

ğŸ¤”Proposition 14. NPâŠ†IPNP\subseteq IPNPâŠ†IP.

An example of a non-trivial interactive proof system for checking that two graph are not isomorphic (GNIGNIGNI).

GNI é—®é¢˜ï¼šåˆ¤æ–­ä¸¤å›¾æ˜¯å¦ä¸æ˜¯åŒæ„çš„ã€‚

Given a graph G=(V,E)G=(V,E)G=(V,E) and a permutation Ï€:Vâ†’V\pi:V\to VÏ€:Vâ†’V. Denote by Ï€(G)\pi(G)Ï€(G) the graph with vertex set VVV and edge set {(Ï€(u),Ï€(v))âˆ£(u,v)âˆˆE}\{(\pi(u),\pi(v))\vert(u,v)\in E\}{(Ï€(u),Ï€(v))âˆ£(u,v)âˆˆE}.

We say that graphs G1(V,E1),G2(V,E2)G_1(V,E_1),G_2(V,E_2)G1â€‹(V,E1â€‹),G2â€‹(V,E2â€‹) with the same set of vertices are isomorphic, denoted G1â‰…G2G_1\cong G_2G1â€‹â‰…G2â€‹, if there exist a permutation Ï€\piÏ€ of VVV s.t. Ï€(G1)=G2\pi(G_1)=G_2Ï€(G1â€‹)=G2â€‹.

Problem of GNIGNIGNI:

  • Instance: Graphs G1(V,E1),G2(V,E2)G_1(V,E_1),G_2(V,E_2)G1â€‹(V,E1â€‹),G2â€‹(V,E2â€‹) on the same set of vertices VVV
  • Question: Is Ï€(G1)â‰ G2\pi(G_1)\neq G_2Ï€(G1â€‹)î€ =G2â€‹ for all permutations Ï€\piÏ€ of VVV?

Clearly, GNIâˆˆcoNPGNI\in coNPGNIâˆˆcoNP. It is not known whether GNIâˆˆNPGNI\in NPGNIâˆˆNP.

A very interesting property of this proof system is that it is a so-called zero-knowledge proof.

é›¶çŸ¥è¯†è¯æ˜ï¼Œæ‰¯åˆ°å¯†ç å­¦ä¸Šå»

ğŸ¯Theorem 48. GNIâˆˆIPGNI\in IPGNIâˆˆIP.

GMW Protocol for GNIGNIGNI:

  • Input: G1=(V,E1),G2=(V,E2)G_1=(V,E_1),G_2=(V,E_2)G1â€‹=(V,E1â€‹),G2â€‹=(V,E2â€‹).
  • Goal: Prove G1â‰…Ì¸G2G_1\not\cong G_2G1â€‹î€ â‰…G2â€‹.

VVV: Pick iâˆˆ{1,2}i\in\{1,2\}iâˆˆ{1,2} and permutation Ï€\piÏ€ of VVV uniformly at random. Send H=Ï€(Gi)H=\pi(G_i)H=Ï€(Giâ€‹) to PPP.

PPP: Pick jâˆˆ{1,2}j\in\{1,2\}jâˆˆ{1,2} s.t. Hâ‰…GjH\cong G_jHâ‰…Gjâ€‹. Send jjj to VVV.

VVV: Accept if i=ji=ji=j. Otherwise reject.

è¿™ä¸ª GMW åè®®æ˜¯ä»€ä¹ˆæ„æ€ï¼šéªŒè¯å™¨éšæœºé€‰ä¸€ä¸ªå›¾å¹¶å°†è¾¹çš„ç¼–å·æ‰“ä¹±ï¼ˆè®°ä¸º HHHï¼‰ï¼Œå‘é€ç»™è¯æ˜å™¨ã€‚è¯æ˜å™¨ä»ä¸¤ä¸ªåŸå›¾ä¸­éšä¾¿é€‰ä¸€ä¸ªå’Œ HHH åŒæ„çš„å›¾ï¼Œå°†å…¶ç¼–å·å‘å›éªŒè¯å™¨ã€‚éªŒè¯å™¨éªŒè¯åŒæ„å›¾ç¼–å·æ˜¯å¦ä¸ HHH å¯¹åº”åŸå›¾çš„ç¼–å·ç›¸ç­‰ã€‚å¦‚æœä¸ç›¸ç­‰çš„è¯ï¼Œé‚£å°±è®¤ä¸ºç»™å®šçš„ä¿©å›¾ä¸åŒæ„ã€‚

Suppose first G1â‰…Ì¸G2G_1\not\cong G_2G1â€‹î€ â‰…G2â€‹. In this case PPP has a unique choice of jjj s.t. Hâ‰…Ì¸GjH\not\cong G_jHî€ â‰…Gjâ€‹, which means that i=ji=ji=j making VVV accept with probability 111. Suppose next that G1â‰…V2G_1\cong V_2G1â€‹â‰…V2â€‹. Then the distribution of Ï€(H)\pi(H)Ï€(H) is independent of iii since the composition of a fixed permutation with a uniformly random permutation is again a uniformly random permutation.

Now since P^\hat PP^ chooses jjj based only on HHH we have Prâ¡[i=j]=1/2\Pr[i=j]=1/2Pr[i=j]=1/2. It follows that the completeness of the protocol is 111 and the soundness error of the protocol is 1/21/21/2. The soundness error may be reduced to 2âˆ’k2^{-k}2âˆ’k by iterating protocol kkk times.

It is not known whether GNIâˆˆNPGNI\in NPGNIâˆˆNP.

ğŸ¤”Proposition 15. IPâˆˆPSPACEIP\in PSPACEIPâˆˆPSPACE.

Hard proof.

The Sumcheck Protocol

How to utilize the power of interactive proofs? Converting Boolean formulas to arithmetic formulas and exploit that polynomials can be evaluated on inputs outside the Boolean cube.

Arithmetization: The process of converting a Boolean formula into an arithmetic formula.

By arithmetization, we can prove that P#PâŠ†IPP^{\#P}\subseteq IPP#PâŠ†IP, where #P\#P#P is a class capturing the complexity of counting the number of satisfying assignments of a Boolean formula.

A weaker result: coNPâŠ†IPcoNP\subseteq IPcoNPâŠ†IP.

The method can be generalized to show PSPACEâŠ†IPPSPACE\subseteq IPPSPACEâŠ†IP.

ğŸ“–Definition 46 (Arithmetization). Let Ï†\varphiÏ† be a 3CNF3CNF3CNF formula with mmm classes C1,â‹¯â€‰,CmC_1,\cdots,C_mC1â€‹,â‹¯,Cmâ€‹ and nnn variables x1,â‹¯â€‰,xnx_1,\cdots,x_nx1â€‹,â‹¯,xnâ€‹. We define the arithmetic formula AÏ†A_\varphiAÏ†â€‹, aka arithmetization of Ï†\varphiÏ†, recursively. For a variable xix_ixiâ€‹ we let A(xi)=xiA(x_i)=x_iA(xiâ€‹)=xiâ€‹, for a negated variable Â¬xi\neg x_iÂ¬xiâ€‹ we let A(Â¬xi)=1âˆ’xiA(\neg x_i)=1-x_iA(Â¬xiâ€‹)=1âˆ’xiâ€‹. For a clause C_j=(\ell_{j,1}\or\ell_{j,2}\or\ell_{j,3}) we let

A(Cj)=1âˆ’A(Â¬Cj)=1âˆ’A(Â¬â„“j,1)A(Â¬â„“j,2)A(Â¬â„“j,3)=1âˆ’(1âˆ’A(â„“j,1))(1âˆ’A(â„“j,2))(1âˆ’A(â„“j,3))A(C_j)=1-A(\neg C_j)=1-A(\neg \ell_{j,1})A(\neg \ell_{j,2})A(\neg \ell_{j,3})\\=1-(1-A(\ell_{j,1}))(1-A(\ell_{j,2}))(1-A(\ell_{j,3}))A(Cjâ€‹)=1âˆ’A(Â¬Cjâ€‹)=1âˆ’A(Â¬â„“j,1â€‹)A(Â¬â„“j,2â€‹)A(Â¬â„“j,3â€‹)=1âˆ’(1âˆ’A(â„“j,1â€‹))(1âˆ’A(â„“j,2â€‹))(1âˆ’A(â„“j,3â€‹))

Finally, we define AÏ†=âˆj=1mA(Cj)A_\varphi=\prod_{j=1}^mA(C_j)AÏ†â€‹=âˆj=1mâ€‹A(Cjâ€‹).

Expanding A(Ï†)A(\varphi)A(Ï†) into a sum of monomials would take exponential time.

The number of satisfying assignments #Ï†\#\varphi#Ï† of Ï†\varphiÏ†:

#Ï†=âˆ‘x1=01âˆ‘x2=01â‹¯âˆ‘xn=01AÏ†(x1,â‹¯â€‰,xn)\#\varphi=\sum_{x_1=0}^1\sum_{x_2=0}^1\cdots\sum_{x_n=0}^1A_\varphi(x_1,\cdots,x_n)#Ï†=x1â€‹=0âˆ‘1â€‹x2â€‹=0âˆ‘1â€‹â‹¯xnâ€‹=0âˆ‘1â€‹AÏ†â€‹(x1â€‹,â‹¯,xnâ€‹)

Then we define an interactive proof for proving #Ï†=K\#\varphi=K#Ï†=K, for given KKK. For K=0K=0K=0 allow us prove that coNPâŠ†IPcoNP\subseteq IPcoNPâŠ†IP. The protocol is called Sumcheck protocol:

  • Input: Arithmetic formula F(x1,â‹¯â€‰,xn)F(x_1,\cdots,x_n)F(x1â€‹,â‹¯,xnâ€‹) of total degree ddd, prime ppp, number KKK.
  • Goal: Prove âˆ‘x1=01âˆ‘x2=01â‹¯âˆ‘xn=01F(x1,â‹¯â€‰,xn)â‰¡Kmodâ€‰â€‰p\sum_{x_1=0}^1\sum_{x_2=0}^1\cdots\sum_{x_n=0}^1F(x_1,\cdots,x_n)\equiv K\mod pâˆ‘x1â€‹=01â€‹âˆ‘x2â€‹=01â€‹â‹¯âˆ‘xnâ€‹=01â€‹F(x1â€‹,â‹¯,xnâ€‹)â‰¡Kmodp.
  • Verifier: If n=0n=0n=0, evaluate the arithmetic formula FFF, which only have constants as inputs. Accept it Fâ‰¡Kmodâ€‰â€‰pF\equiv K\mod pFâ‰¡Kmodp and reject otherwise. If Nâ‰¥1N\ge1Nâ‰¥1, await message from PPP.
  • Prover: Send the uni-variate degree ddd polynomial Q(x1)Q(x_1)Q(x1â€‹) to Verifier, where Q(x1)Q(x_1)Q(x1â€‹) is given by Q(x1)=âˆ‘x2=01â‹¯âˆ‘xn=01F(x1,â‹¯â€‰,xn)Q(x_1)=\sum_{x_2=0}^1\cdots\sum_{x_n=0}^1F(x_1,\cdots,x_n)Q(x1â€‹)=âˆ‘x2â€‹=01â€‹â‹¯âˆ‘xnâ€‹=01â€‹F(x1â€‹,â‹¯,xnâ€‹).
  • Verifier: If Q(0)+Q(1)â‰¡Ì¸Kmodâ€‰â€‰pQ(0)+Q(1)\not\equiv K\mod pQ(0)+Q(1)î€ â‰¡Kmodp, reject. Otherwise, pick a1âˆˆZpa_1\in\mathbb Z_pa1â€‹âˆˆZpâ€‹ uniformly at random. Send a1a_1a1â€‹ to PPP and recursively invoke the protocol for proving that âˆ‘x2=01â‹¯âˆ‘xn=01F(a1,x2,â‹¯â€‰,xn)â‰¡Q(a1)modâ€‰â€‰p\sum_{x_2=0}^1\cdots\sum_{x_n=0}^1F(a_1,x_2,\cdots,x_n)\equiv Q(a_1)\mod pâˆ‘x2â€‹=01â€‹â‹¯âˆ‘xnâ€‹=01â€‹F(a1â€‹,x2â€‹,â‹¯,xnâ€‹)â‰¡Q(a1â€‹)modp.

ğŸ¤”Proposition 16. Let F(x1,â‹¯â€‰,xn)F(x_1,\cdots,x_n)F(x1â€‹,â‹¯,xnâ€‹) be an arithmetic formula of total degree ddd, which is polynomial in nnn, let ppp be a prime of bi-length polynomial in nnn, and let KKK be an integer. The Sumcheck protocol is an interactive proof for the statement

âˆ‘x1=01âˆ‘x2=01â‹¯âˆ‘xn=01F(x1,â‹¯â€‰,xn)â‰¡Kmodâ€‰â€‰p\sum_{x_1=0}^1\sum_{x_2=0}^1\cdots\sum_{x_n=0}^1F(x_1,\cdots,x_n)\equiv K\mod px1â€‹=0âˆ‘1â€‹x2â€‹=0âˆ‘1â€‹â‹¯xnâ€‹=0âˆ‘1â€‹F(x1â€‹,â‹¯,xnâ€‹)â‰¡Kmodp

with completeness 111 and soundness error at most nd/pnd/pnd/p.

ğŸ¤”Corollary 11. coNPâŠ†IPcoNP\subseteq IPcoNPâŠ†IP.

Show that 3SATâ€¾âˆˆIP\overline{3SAT}\in IP3SATâˆˆIP.

Interactive Proof for Polynomial Space

PSPACEâŠ†IPPSPACE\subseteq IPPSPACEâŠ†IP

Consider PSPACEPSPACEPSPACE-complete TQBFTQBFTQBF.

Consider whether Ïˆ=âˆƒx1âˆˆ{0,1}âˆ€x2âˆˆ{0,1}â‹¯âˆƒxnâˆˆ{0,1}Ï†(x1,â‹¯â€‰,xn)\psi=\exist x_1\in\{0,1\}\forall x_2\in\{0,1\}\cdots\exist x_n\in\{0,1\}\varphi(x_1,\cdots,x_n)Ïˆ=âˆƒx1â€‹âˆˆ{0,1}âˆ€x2â€‹âˆˆ{0,1}â‹¯âˆƒxnâ€‹âˆˆ{0,1}Ï†(x1â€‹,â‹¯,xnâ€‹) is true.

WLOG, quantifiers are strictly alternating, Ï†\varphiÏ† is a 3CNF3CNF3CNF formula with nnn variables and mmm clauses.

Note that Ïˆ\psiÏˆ is true iff

âˆ‘x1âˆx2âˆ‘x3â‹¯âˆ‘xnAÏ†(x1,â‹¯â€‰,xn)>0.\sum_{x_1}\prod_{x_2}\sum_{x_3}\cdots\sum_{x_n}A_\varphi(x_1,\cdots,x_n)\gt0.x1â€‹âˆ‘â€‹x2â€‹âˆâ€‹x3â€‹âˆ‘â€‹â‹¯xnâ€‹âˆ‘â€‹AÏ†â€‹(x1â€‹,â‹¯,xnâ€‹)>0.

Unbinding outermost summation over x1x_1x1â€‹ is polynomial of exponential degree.

One solution to around the obstacle: limiting the scope of each variable using variable renaming.

Making use of linearization for the same purpose:

ğŸ“–Definition 47. Let Q(x1,â‹¯â€‰,xn)Q(x_1,\cdots,x_n)Q(x1â€‹,â‹¯,xnâ€‹) be a polynomial. By Lxi\large\mathbf L_{x_i}Lxiâ€‹â€‹ binds the variable xix_ixiâ€‹, at the same time introducing a new variable xix_ixiâ€‹ (reusing the variable name xix_ixiâ€‹). Now replace the condition âˆ‘x1âˆx2âˆ‘x3â‹¯âˆ‘xnAÏ†(x1,â‹¯â€‰,xn)>0\sum_{x_1}\prod_{x_2}\sum_{x_3}\cdots\sum_{x_n}A_\varphi(x_1,\cdots,x_n)\gt0âˆ‘x1â€‹â€‹âˆx2â€‹â€‹âˆ‘x3â€‹â€‹â‹¯âˆ‘xnâ€‹â€‹AÏ†â€‹(x1â€‹,â‹¯,xnâ€‹)>0 by

âˆ‘x1Lx1âˆ‘x2Lx1Lx2â‹¯âˆ‘xnLx1â‹¯LxnAÏ†(x1,â‹¯â€‰,xn)>0.\sum_{x_1}\mathbf L_{x_1}\sum_{x_2}\mathbf L_{x_1}\mathbf L_{x_2}\cdots\sum_{x_n}\mathbf L_{x_1}\cdots\mathbf L_{x_n}A_\varphi(x_1,\cdots,x_n)\gt0.x1â€‹âˆ‘â€‹Lx1â€‹â€‹x2â€‹âˆ‘â€‹Lx1â€‹â€‹Lx2â€‹â€‹â‹¯xnâ€‹âˆ‘â€‹Lx1â€‹â€‹â‹¯Lxnâ€‹â€‹AÏ†â€‹(x1â€‹,â‹¯,xnâ€‹)>0.

The extension of the Sumcheck protocol:

  • The prover sends a prime ppp and a number Kâ‰¡Ì¸0modâ€‰â€‰pK\not\equiv0\mod pKî€ â‰¡0modp s.t. the LHS is KÂ modÂ pK\text{ mod }pKÂ modÂ p.

    The LHS is a non-negative integer of magnitude at most 22n2^{2^n}22n, hence is divisible by ay most 2n2^n2n distinct primes.

    By property of prime distribution function, the prime ppp has bit-length n+O(logâ¡n)n+O(\log n)n+O(logn).

  • Each of the operators of the form âˆ‘xi,âˆxi,Lxi\sum_{x_i},\prod_{x_i},\mathbf L_{x_i}âˆ‘xiâ€‹â€‹,âˆxiâ€‹â€‹,Lxiâ€‹â€‹ are unbound one by one, and PPP sends the resulting uni-variate polynomial Q(xi)Q(x_i)Q(xiâ€‹).

  • â€¦

ğŸ¯Theorem 49. IP=PSPACEIP=PSPACEIP=PSPACE.

Two interesting observation:

  1. The completeness of the extended Sumcheck protocol is 111. Any interactive proof system may be converted into an equivalent interactive proof system with completeness 111.
  2. The message sent to the Prover by the Verifier may be viewed as just consisting of all random bits read since the last message sent.

entry.title: Fair AI/ML 3 PROP Fair Clustering Revisited
entry.content:
Read the paper Proportionally Fair Clustering Revisited by Micha et Shah.

kkk cluster centers must be placed given nnn points in a metric space.

The cost to each point is its distance to the nearest cluster center.

This paper: Focus on the case where cluster centers can be placed anywhere in metric space.

E.g. L2L^2L2 distance over Rt\mathbb R^tRt, the approximation ratio of greedy capture improves to 222.

For L1,LâˆL^1,L^\inftyL1,Lâˆ metric, the approximation ratio remains 1+21+\sqrt 21+2â€‹.

The paper gives universal lower bounds which apply to all algorithms.

Introduction

Points N\mathcal NN, possible cluster centers M\mathcal MM.

Given kâˆˆNk\in\mathbb NkâˆˆN, task is to select a set XâŠ†MX\subseteq\mathcal MXâŠ†M consisting of âˆ£Xâˆ£=k|X|=kâˆ£Xâˆ£=k cluster centers.

Group fairness.

Proportional fairness.

Contribution

Focus on the case where the metric consists of usual distance functions such as L1,L2,LâˆL^1,L^2,L^\inftyL1,L2,Lâˆ over Rt\mathbb R^tRt.

âš ï¸Cluster centers can be placed anywhere in the infinite metric space. M=Rt\mathcal M=\mathbb R^tM=Rtâ—

è¯·æ³¨æ„æ­¤å¤„ï¼Œå€™é€‰èšç±»ä¸­å¿ƒå’Œä¸Šä¸€ç¯‡è®ºæ–‡ä¸ä¸€æ ·ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥å¾—å‡ºçš„è¿‘ä¼¼ä¸‹ç•Œä¸ä¸€æ ·ã€‚

Greedy Capture by Chen et al. where dâˆˆ{L1,L2,Lâˆ}d\in\{L^1,L^2,L^\infty\}dâˆˆ{L1,L2,Lâˆ} and M=Rt\mathcal M=\mathbb R^tM=Rt.

For d=L2,M=Rtd=L^2,\mathcal M=\mathbb R^td=L2,M=Rt, GC provides 222-PROP. The approximation is obtained by Apollonius radius.

For L1,LâˆL^1,L^\inftyL1,Lâˆ, the approximation ratio can not be better than 1+21+\sqrt21+2â€‹.

Universal lower bounds: for d=L2d=L^2d=L2 and M=Rt\mathcal M=\mathbb R^tM=Rt, no algorithm achieves better than 23â‰ˆ1.155\frac{2}{\sqrt 3}\approx1.1553â€‹2â€‹â‰ˆ1.155-PROP, whereas for dâˆˆ{L1,Lâˆ}d\in\{L^1,L^\infty\}dâˆˆ{L1,Lâˆ} and M=Rt\mathcal M=\mathbb R^tM=Rt, the lower bound is 1.41.41.4.

Also, this paper consider the case where M\mathcal MM is the set of nodes of an unweighted graph, and ddd measures the shortest distance between two nodes on the graph.

  • If the graph is a tree, then PROP must exist. And there are an efficient algorithm.
  • If the graph is arbitrary, kâ‰¥n/2k\ge n/2kâ‰¥n/2. PROP must exist and can be computed efficiently.
  • Open problem: Whether an exact PROP exists for all graphs.

For d=L2d=L^2d=L2 and M=Rt\mathcal M=\mathbb R^tM=Rt for tâ‰¥2t\ge2tâ‰¥2, checking whether a clustering is PROP is NP-hard.

When ttt is large,even greedy capture is NP-hard. When ttt is constant, the problem becomes efficiently solvable.

When ttt is large, using a PTASPTASPTAS as sub-routine of greedy capture, we can efficiently compute 2(1+Ïµ)2(1+\epsilon)2(1+Ïµ)-PROP fair clustering for any fixed Ïµ>0\epsilon\gt0Ïµ>0

Problem of generalization: Would a clustering that is PROP w.r.t. samples drawn from N\mathcal NN remain approximately PROP w.r.t. entire set N\mathcal NN? Chen et al. proved that the answer is yes when âˆ£Mâˆ£|\mathcal M|âˆ£Mâˆ£ is finite. Using the VC dimension, the answer is also yes for M=Rt\mathcal M=\mathbb R^tM=Rt.

Preliminaries

N\mathcal NN: the set of nnn data points lie in a metric space (X,d)(\mathcal X,d)(X,d), where d:XÃ—Xâ†’Rd:\mathcal X\times\mathcal X\to\mathbb Rd:XÃ—Xâ†’R is a distance function satisfying the triangle inequality.

Consider X=Rt\mathcal X=\mathbb R^tX=Rt for tâˆˆNt\in\mathbb NtâˆˆN.

Distance function: L2,L1,LâˆL^2,L^1,L^\inftyL2,L1,Lâˆ.

M\mathcal MM: set of candidate cluster centers. In this paper M=X\mathcal M=\mathcal XM=X.

Given kâˆˆNk\in\mathbb NkâˆˆN, a kkk-clustering is a set XâˆˆMkX\in\mathcal M^kXâˆˆMk.

Each xâˆˆXx\in XxâˆˆX is called the open cluster center.

Cost to agent iâˆˆNi\in\mathcal NiâˆˆN induced by a cluster center xâˆˆMx\in\mathcal MxâˆˆM is the distance d(i,x)d(i,x)d(i,x). The cost to agent iii should be the minimal distance.

d(i,X)=minâ¡xâˆˆXd(i,x)d(i,X)=\min_{x\in X}d(i,x)d(i,X)=xâˆˆXminâ€‹d(i,x)

Agent iii is interested in minimizing the cost.

A set of points SâŠ†NS\subseteq NSâŠ†N containing at least âŒˆn/kâŒ‰\lceil n/k\rceilâŒˆn/kâŒ‰, if they can find a new cluster that is better for each of them, it is a violation of fairness (block coalition)

ğŸ“–Definition 1. Ï\rhoÏ-PROP, block coalition. Omitted.

PROP on graphs: given an undirected graph G=(V,E)G=(V,E)G=(V,E), NâŠ†V,M=V\mathcal N\subseteq V,\mathcal M=VNâŠ†V,M=V. Distance between u,vâˆˆVu,v\in Vu,vâˆˆV is the length of the shortest path.

Greedy Capture

Detail is omitted here.

(1+2)(1+\sqrt2)(1+2â€‹)-PROP

This paper gives a refined analysis of Greedy Capture.

ğŸ“–Definition 2 (Apollonius radius) Given Ïâ‰¥1\rho\ge1Ïâ‰¥1, the Ï\rhoÏ-Apollonius radius of a metric (X,d)(\mathcal X,d)(X,d) is defined as AX,d(Ï)=supâ¡x,yâˆˆXÎ”(Ï,x,y)/d(x,y)A_{\mathcal X,d}(\rho)=\sup_{x,y\in\mathcal X}\Delta(\rho,x,y)/d(x,y)AX,dâ€‹(Ï)=supx,yâˆˆXâ€‹Î”(Ï,x,y)/d(x,y), where Î”(Ï,x,y)\Delta(\rho,x,y)Î”(Ï,x,y) is the radius of the smallest ball centered at some point in X\mathcal XX that contains the entire set {pâˆˆX:Ïâ‹…d(p,y)â‰¤d(p,x)}\{p\in\mathcal X:\rho\cdot d(p,y)\le d(p,x)\}{pâˆˆX:Ïâ‹…d(p,y)â‰¤d(p,x)}.

When Ï>1\rho\gt1Ï>1, the set is a ball.

ğŸ¯Theorem 3. For any metric (X,d)(\mathcal X,d)(X,d) and M=X\mathcal M=\mathcal XM=X, greedy capture finds a Ï\rhoÏ-PROP clustering, where Ïâ‰¥1\rho\ge1Ïâ‰¥1 is the smallest positive number satisfying AX,d(Ï)â‹…Ï+1Ïâ‰¤1A_{\mathcal X,d}(\rho)\cdot\frac{\rho+1}{\rho}\le1AX,dâ€‹(Ï)â‹…ÏÏ+1â€‹â‰¤1.

M=X\mathcal M=\mathcal XM=X: å€™é€‰èšç±»ä¸­å¿ƒå¯ä»¥æ˜¯ç©ºé—´ä¸Šä»»æ„ä¸€ç‚¹ã€‚

Proof by triangle inequality. Proof that if XXX is not Ï\rhoÏ-PROP, then AX,d(Ï)â‹…Ï+1Ï>1A_{\mathcal X,d}(\rho)\cdot\frac{\rho+1}{\rho}\gt1AX,dâ€‹(Ï)â‹…ÏÏ+1â€‹>1.

ğŸ¯Theorem 4. For any metric (X,d)(\mathcal X,d)(X,d), the Ï\rhoÏ-Apollonius radius is AX,d(Ï)â‰¤1Ïâˆ’1A_{\mathcal X,d}(\rho)\le\frac{1}{\rho-1}AX,dâ€‹(Ï)â‰¤Ïâˆ’11â€‹. Hence, greedy capture finds a (1+2)(1+\sqrt2)(1+2â€‹)-PROP fair clustering for every metric.

åœ¨æˆ‘çœ‹æ¥ï¼Œæœ¬ç¯‡è®ºæ–‡å®šä¹‰äº†ä¸€ä¸ªå¤æ‚çš„æ¦‚å¿µâ€”â€”é˜¿æ³¢ç½—å°¼ä¹Œæ–¯åŠå¾„ï¼Œæ¥å½¢å¼åŒ–è¯æ˜ç®—æ³•ç»“æœçš„ä¸‹ç•Œã€‚

ä½†æ˜¯è¿™ä¸ªé˜¿æ³¢ç½—å°¼ä¹Œæ–¯åŠå¾„çš„å®šä¹‰è¿‡äºå¤æ‚äº†ã€‚

Next, the paper shows for d=L2d=L^2d=L2, the Ï\rhoÏ-Apollonius radius is better, 222-PROP guarantee.

ğŸ¯Theorem 5. For the metric space (R2,L2)(\mathbb R^2,L^2)(R2,L2), where tâˆˆNt\in\mathbb NtâˆˆN, the Ï\rhoÏ-Apollonius radius AR2,L2(Ï)â‰¤ÏÏ2âˆ’1A_{\mathbb R^2,L^2}(\rho)\le\frac{\rho}{\rho^2-1}AR2,L2â€‹(Ï)â‰¤Ï2âˆ’1Ïâ€‹, and hence, greedy capture finds a 222-PROP clustering.

Proof omitted.

Whether the introduction of Apollonius improves approximation bound for other distance metrics. For L1,LâˆL^1,L^\inftyL1,Lâˆ, the answer is unfortunately NO. The approximation remains 1+21+\sqrt 21+2â€‹.

ğŸ¯Theorem 6. For the metric space (Rt,d)(\mathbb R^t,d)(Rt,d) where tâ‰¥2t\ge2tâ‰¥2 and dâˆˆ{L1,Lâˆ}d\in\{L^1,L^\infty\}dâˆˆ{L1,Lâˆ}, and M=Rt\mathcal M=\mathbb R^tM=Rt, there exists an example in which the clustering produced by greedy capture is not Ï\rhoÏ-PROP for Ï<1+2\rho\lt1+\sqrt2Ï<1+2â€‹.

Universal Lower Bounds

This paper generalizes lower bounds on approximation to PROP that apply to ALL ALGORITHMS.

Chen et al. showed that Ï<2\rho<2Ï<2 is not guaranteed. For N=M\mathcal N=\mathcal MN=M, the weaker lower bound 1.51.51.5.

This paper: for the case where M=X=Rt\mathcal M=\mathcal X=\mathbb R^tM=X=Rt and dâˆˆ{L1,L2,Lâˆ}d\in\{L^1,L^2,L^\infty\}dâˆˆ{L1,L2,Lâˆ}.

å†æ¬¡æé†’ï¼šM=X\mathcal M=\mathcal XM=X: å€™é€‰èšç±»ä¸­å¿ƒå¯ä»¥æ˜¯ç©ºé—´ä¸Šä»»æ„ä¸€ç‚¹ã€‚

  • When t=1t=1t=1, itâ€™s easy to see that there always exist PROP clusterings.
  • When tâ‰¥2t\ge2tâ‰¥2, a lower bound 2/32/\sqrt32/3â€‹ for d=L2d=L^2d=L2 and a lower bound 1.41.41.4 for dâˆˆ{L1,Lâˆ}d\in\{L^1,L^\infty\}dâˆˆ{L1,Lâˆ}.

ğŸ¯Theorem 7. For the metric space (Rt,L2)(\mathbb R^t,L^2)(Rt,L2) where tâ‰¥2t\ge2tâ‰¥2 and M=Rt\mathcal M=\mathbb R^tM=Rt, there is an example in which no clustering is Ï\rhoÏ-PROP for p<2/3â‰ˆ1.155p\lt2/\sqrt3\approx1.155p<2/3â€‹â‰ˆ1.155.

Closing the gap between lower bound 1.1551.1551.155 and upper bound 222 for L2L^2L2 is an open problem.

ğŸ¯Theorem 8. For the metric space (Rt,d)(\mathbb R^t,d)(Rt,d), where tâ‰¥2t\ge2tâ‰¥2 and dâˆˆ{L1,Lâˆ}d\in\{L^1,L^\infty\}dâˆˆ{L1,Lâˆ}, and M=Rt\mathcal M=\mathbb R^tM=Rt, there is an example in which no clustering is Ï\rhoÏ-PROP for Ï<1.4\rho\lt1.4Ï<1.4.

Clustering in Graphs

In this section, we consider the special case where the metric space (X,d)(\mathcal X,d)(X,d) is induced by an undirected graph G=(V,E)G=(V,E)G=(V,E).

Consider the case of M=X=V\mathcal M=\mathcal X=VM=X=V. Distance d(x,y)d(x,y)d(x,y) is the length of the shortest path between x,yx,yx,y.

æ‰€æœ‰èŠ‚ç‚¹éƒ½æ˜¯å€™é€‰èšç±»ä¸­å¿ƒï¼Œè·ç¦»å®šä¹‰ä¸ºæœ€çŸ­è·¯é•¿åº¦ã€‚

When GGG is a tree, an exact PROP clustering always exists, and can be computed by an efficient algorithm.

PROP Clustering for Trees

First root the tree at an arbitrary node rrr to obtain a rooted tree (G,r)(G,r)(G,r).

Denote with hhh the height of the rooted rooted tree, and with level(x)level(x)level(x) the height of node xxx relative to root rrr with level(r)=1level(r)=1level(r)=1.

Let ST(x)ST(x)ST(x) denote the sub-tree of node xxx

The algorithm starts from the leaves, opens a center every time it finds a node whose sub-tree contains at least âŒˆn/kâŒ‰\lceil n/k\rceilâŒˆn/kâŒ‰ nodes, then deletes this sub-tree from the graph. At the end, the cost to each node is still defined using the closest node at which a center is opened by the algorithm.

Pseudo Code - PROP Clustering for Trees

  1. Root the tree GGG at an arbitrary node rrr.
  2. Xâ†âˆ…X\gets\emptyXâ†âˆ…
  3. Gdâ†GG^d\gets GGdâ†G.
  4. for â„“=d\ell=dâ„“=d to 111 do
    1. Gâ„“âˆ’1=Gâ„“G^{\ell-1}=G^\ellGâ„“âˆ’1=Gâ„“
    2. for every xâˆˆVx\in VxâˆˆV with level(x)=llevel(x)=llevel(x)=l and âˆ£ST(x)âˆ£â‰¥âŒˆn/kâŒ‰|ST(x)|\ge\lceil n/k\rceilâˆ£ST(x)âˆ£â‰¥âŒˆn/kâŒ‰ do
      • Xâ†Xâˆª{x}X\gets X\cup\{x\}Xâ†Xâˆª{x}
      • Gâ„“âˆ’1â†Gâ„“âˆ’1â•²ST(x)G^{\ell-1}\gets G^{\ell-1}\diagdown ST(x)Gâ„“âˆ’1â†Gâ„“âˆ’1â•²ST(x)
  5. if G0â‰ âˆ…G^0\neq\emptyG0î€ =âˆ… then Xâ†Xâˆª{r}X\gets X\cup\{r\}Xâ†Xâˆª{r}
  6. return XXX

ğŸ¯Theorem 9. Let G=(V,E)G=(V,E)G=(V,E) be an undirected tree, (V,d)(V,d)(V,d) be the metric induced by GGG, NâŠ†V,M=V\mathcal N\subseteq V,\mathcal M=VNâŠ†V,M=V, and kâˆˆNk\in\mathbb NkâˆˆN. Then, the algorithm yields a PROP clustering.

Hard proof by contradiction.

What about Non-tree

Consider the universal lower bound for (R2,L1)(\mathbb R^2,L^1)(R2,L1) metric from Theorem 8.

If the graph is dense enough, we can derive same lower bound of 1.41.41.4.

â“Whether better lower bounds exist is an open problem.

â“For special case where N=V\mathcal N=VN=V, we do not know whether PROP always exists

If GGG is connected and we want to place a large number of clusters kâ‰¥n/2k\ge n/2kâ‰¥n/2, then PROP always exists. This is because a dominating set of any size kâ‰¥n/2k\ge n/2kâ‰¥n/2 is guaranteed to exist in a graph with nnn nodes and can be computed efficiently.

Definition of dominating set: A set of nodes is called a dominating set if every node in the graph is either in this set or adjacent to a node in this set.

Thus the problem of finding a PROP clustering in general graphs with N=M=V\mathcal N=\mathcal M=VN=M=V is trivial when kâ‰¥n/2k\ge n/2kâ‰¥n/2, but remains open when k<n/2k\lt n/2k<n/2.

Computational Aspects

Two problems:

  1. Checking whether a PROP clustering exits.
  2. Implementing the Greedy Capture when M=Rt\mathcal M=\mathbb R^tM=Rt.

ğŸ¯Theorem 10, Given a finite N\mathcal NN, finite M\mathcal MM, kâˆˆNk\in\mathbb NkâˆˆN, and d=L2d=L^2d=L2, checking whether a PROP clustering exists is NP-hard.

Polynomial-time reduction from the planar monotone rectilinear 3-SAT problem.

Planar monotone rectilinear 3-SAT problem: Given a 3-SAT formula, each clause cjc_jcjâ€‹ consists of only positive or only negative literals, the graph connecting clauses to literals they contain is planar, and this graph has a planar embedding in which each variable viv_iviâ€‹ is represented by a rectangle on the xxx-axis and each positive/negative clause is represented by a rectangle above/below xxx-axis with 3 vertical lines or legs to its 3 variables.

ä»€ä¹ˆç©æ„å•Šï¼Œä»€ä¹ˆä¹±ä¸ƒå…«ç³Ÿçš„ NP-hard é—®é¢˜ã€‚æ¬ºè´Ÿæˆ‘ä¸ä¼šè¯è§„çº¦æ˜¯å§ã€‚

ğŸ¯Theorem 11. Let tâˆˆNt\in\mathbb NtâˆˆN, finite NâŠ‚Rt\mathcal N\subset\mathbb R^tNâŠ‚Rt, and kâˆˆNk\in\mathbb NkâˆˆN be given as input. Suppose M=Rt\mathcal M=\mathbb R^tM=Rt and d=L2d=L^2d=L2. Then, the following hold:

  1. The clustering returned by Greedy Capture algorithm cannot be computed in polynomial time unless P=NPP=NPP=NP.
  2. If ttt is constant, then it can be computed in polynomial time.
  3. Even if ttt is not constant, for any constant Ïµ>0\epsilon>0Ïµ>0, there exists a polynomial time algorithm which finds a (2+Ïµ)(2+\epsilon)(2+Ïµ)-PROP clustering.

Learning Fair Clustering by Sampling

VERY DIFFICULT!

Is a clustering that is approximately PROP w.r.t. random samples taken from an underlying population would remain approximately PROP w.r.t. the whole population.

YES!

ğŸ“–Definition 12. We say that a kkk-clustering XXX is Ï\rhoÏ-PROP fair to (1+Ïµ)(1+\epsilon)(1+Ïµ)-deviations w.r.t. N\mathcal NN if for all SâŠ†NS\subseteq\mathcal NSâŠ†N with âˆ£Sâˆ£â‰¥âˆ£Nâˆ£â‹…(1+Ïµ)/k|S|\ge|\mathcal N|\cdot(1+\epsilon)/kâˆ£Sâˆ£â‰¥âˆ£Nâˆ£â‹…(1+Ïµ)/k and all yâˆˆMy\in\mathcal MyâˆˆM, there exists at least one iâˆˆSi\in SiâˆˆS s.t. Ïâ‹…d(i,y)â‰¥d(i,X)\rho\cdot d(i,y)\ge d(i,X)Ïâ‹…d(i,y)â‰¥d(i,X).

ğŸ“–Definition 13. Given a set of points N\mathcal NN, a kkk-clustering XXX, and yâˆˆMy\in\mathcal MyâˆˆM, define the binary classifier hX,y:Nâ†’{0,1}h_{X,y}:\mathcal N\to\{0,1\}hX,yâ€‹:Nâ†’{0,1} s.t. hX,y(i)=1h_{X,y}(i)=1hX,yâ€‹(i)=1 iff Ïâ‹…d(i,y)<d(i,X)\rho\cdot d(i,y)\lt d(i,X)Ïâ‹…d(i,y)<d(i,X). Define the error of this classifier on a set of points SâŠ†NS\subseteq\mathcal NSâŠ†N as errS(hX,y)=(1/âˆ£Sâˆ£)â‹…âˆ‘iâˆˆShX,y(i)err_S(h_{X,y})=(1/|S|)\cdot\sum_{i\in S}h_{X,y}(i)errSâ€‹(hX,yâ€‹)=(1/âˆ£Sâˆ£)â‹…âˆ‘iâˆˆSâ€‹hX,yâ€‹(i).

The classifier equals 111 iff iii can be part of a coalition that complains about the unfairness of XXX by demonstrating yyy as a location that provides them Ï\rhoÏ-improvement.

XXX is Ï\rhoÏ-PROP to (1+Ïµ)(1+\epsilon)(1+Ïµ)-deviations w.r.t. N\mathcal NN iff errN(X,y)â‰¤1+Ïµkerr_\mathcal N(X,y)\le\frac{1+\epsilon}{k}errNâ€‹(X,y)â‰¤k1+Ïµâ€‹ for all yâˆˆMy\in\mathcal MyâˆˆM.

Goal: Show that given a large enough random simple NâŠ†NN\subseteq\mathcal NNâŠ†N, if we have clustering XXX that is Ï\rhoÏ-PROP w.r.t. NNN, then it is Ï\rhoÏ-PROP to (1+Ïµ)(1+\epsilon)(1+Ïµ)-deviations w.r.t. N\mathcal NN with high probability. But there is no control over X,yX,yX,y. Because of the uniform convergence guarantee.

âˆ£errN(hX,y)âˆ’errN(hX,y)âˆ£|err_N(h_{X,y})-err_\mathcal N(h_{X,y})|âˆ£errNâ€‹(hX,yâ€‹)âˆ’errNâ€‹(hX,yâ€‹)âˆ£ is bounded for all X,yX,yX,y.

ğŸ“–Definition 14 (VC Dimension). Let N\mathcal NN be a set of points. Let H\mathcal HH be a family of binary classifier over N\mathcal NN. We say that H\mathcal HH shatters SâŠ†NS\subseteq\mathcal NSâŠ†N if for every labeling â„“:Sâ†’{0,1}\ell:S\to\{0,1\}â„“:Sâ†’{0,1}, there exists a classifier hâˆˆHh\in\mathcal HhâˆˆH s.t. h(i)=â„“(i)h(i)=\ell(i)h(i)=â„“(i) for all iâˆˆSi\in SiâˆˆS. The VC dimension of H\mathcal HH, denoted dimVC(H)dim^{VC}(\mathcal H)dimVC(H), is the size of the largest SSS that can be shattered by H\mathcal HH.

ğŸ¤”Proposition 15. Let H\mathcal HH be a family of binary classifier over a set of points N\mathcal NN. If NâŠ†NN\subseteq NNâŠ†N is a uniformly random sample with âˆ£Nâˆ£â‰¥Î©(dimVC(H)+lnâ¡(1/Î´)Ïµ2)|N|\ge\Omega\left(\frac{dim^{VC}(\mathcal H)+\ln(1/\delta)}{\epsilon^2}\right)âˆ£Nâˆ£â‰¥Î©(Ïµ2dimVC(H)+ln(1/Î´)â€‹), then with probability at least 1âˆ’Î´1-\delta1âˆ’Î´, âˆ£errN(h)âˆ’errN(h)âˆ£â‰¤Ïµ|err_N(h)-err_\mathcal N(h)|\le\epsilonâˆ£errNâ€‹(h)âˆ’errNâ€‹(h)âˆ£â‰¤Ïµ for all hâˆˆHh\in\mathcal HhâˆˆH.

ğŸ¯Theorem 16. Fix Ïµ,Î´>0,Ïâ‰¥1,k,tâˆˆN\epsilon,\delta\gt0,\rho\ge1,k,t\in\NÏµ,Î´>0,Ïâ‰¥1,k,tâˆˆN, and metric (X,d)(\mathcal X,d)(X,d) where X=Rt\mathcal X=\R^tX=Rt and d=L2d=L^2d=L2. Let N\mathcal NN be a set of points and M=Rt\mathcal M=\R^tM=Rt be the set of candidate centers. Let NâŠ†NN\subseteq\mathcal NNâŠ†N be sampled uniformly at random with âˆ£Nâˆ£â‰¥Î©(k2â‹…(tklnâ¡k+lnâ¡(1/Î´))Ïµ2)|N|\ge\Omega\left(\frac{k^2\cdot(tk\ln k+\ln(1/\delta))}{\epsilon^2}\right)âˆ£Nâˆ£â‰¥Î©(Ïµ2k2â‹…(tklnk+ln(1/Î´))â€‹). Then with probability at least 1âˆ’Î´1-\delta1âˆ’Î´, every kkk-clustering XâˆˆMkX\in\mathcal M^kXâˆˆMk that is Ï\rhoÏ-PROP w.r.t. NNN is Ï\rhoÏ-PROP to (1+Ïµ)(1+\epsilon)(1+Ïµ)-deviation w.r.t. N\mathcal NN.

Open Questions

This paper mainly consider M\mathcal MM is entire metric space.

There are some open questions.

Bridging Gaps

Can we bridge the lower (1+2)(1+\sqrt2)(1+2â€‹) and upper bounds on the approximation ratio to PROP.

Conjecture for L2L^2L2, the lower bound 2/32/\sqrt32/3â€‹ may be achievable.

Maybe by Jungâ€™s theorem, for L2L^2L2 distance in R2\R^2R2, any set of points with diameter at most 111 is contained in a ball of radius at most 1/31/\sqrt31/3â€‹. This could be useful in closing the gap for L2L^2L2.

On Graphs

Does PROP clustering always exist for all graphs when N=M\mathcal N=\mathcal MN=M is the set of all nodes of the graph?

Computational Hardness

What is the computational hardness for other distance metrics?

Other ML Models

Can we adapt this PROP to other machine learning settings such as regression or classification?

Some Personal Unremarkable Rants

This paper revisit Greedy Capture. But remember M=\mathcal M=M= whole metric space, this gives different bounds.

Some dazzling new concepts like â€œApollonius radiusâ€, â€œshatterâ€ etc.

Impressive spectacular showmanship on hardness proof.
entry.summary: Read the paper

entry.title: Fair AI/ML 2 PROP Fair Clustering
entry.content:
Read the paper Proportionally Fair Clustering by Chen et al.

Abstract

nnn points, kkk centers.

Proportionality: any n/kn/kn/k points are entitled to form own cluster if there is another center that is closer in distance for all n/kn/kn/k points.

Clustering with no justified complaints from any subset of agents.

Tradeoff between proportional solutions and kkk-means objective.

Introduction

In centroid clustering, we want to partition data into kkk clusters by choosing kkk centers and then matching points to one of the centers.

Each data point represents a individual. We with the clustering to be fair. These agents prefer to be clustered accurately.

A clustering is fair if it respects the entitlements of groups of agents: a subset of agents is entitled to choose a center for themselves if they constitute a sufficiently large fraction of the population w.r.t. the total number of clusters. No priori knowledge about which points should be protected.

Preliminaries

N\mathcal NN data points, âˆ£Nâˆ£=n|\mathcal N|=nâˆ£Nâˆ£=n.

M\mathcal MM feasible cluster centers, âˆ£Mâˆ£=m|\mathcal M|=mâˆ£Mâˆ£=m.

For i,jâˆˆMâˆªNi,j\in\mathcal M\cup\mathcal Ni,jâˆˆMâˆªN, we have distance (i,j)(i,j)(i,j) satisfying the triangle inequality.

Open a set XâŠ†MX\subseteq\mathcal MXâŠ†M of âˆ£Xâˆ£=k|X|=kâˆ£Xâˆ£=k centers, and then match all points in N\mathcal NN to the closest center in XXX.

For a particular solution XXX and agent iâˆˆNi\in\mathcal NiâˆˆN, let Di(X)=minâ¡xâˆˆXd(i,x)D_i(X)=\min_{x\in X}d(i,x)Diâ€‹(X)=minxâˆˆXâ€‹d(i,x). A good clustering solution XXX will have small values of Di(X)D_i(X)Diâ€‹(X).

Different measures, different objectives:

  • kkk-median: âˆ‘iâˆˆNDi(X)\sum_{i\in\mathcal N}D_i(X)âˆ‘iâˆˆNâ€‹Diâ€‹(X)
  • kkk-means: âˆ‘iâˆˆN(Di(X))2\sum_{i\in\mathcal N}(D_i(X))^2âˆ‘iâˆˆNâ€‹(Diâ€‹(X))2
  • kkk-center: maxâ¡iâˆˆNDi(X)\max_{i\in\mathcal N}D_i(X)maxiâˆˆNâ€‹Diâ€‹(X)

Individuals prefer to be closer to their center in terms of distance.

ğŸ“–Definition 1. Let XâŠ†MX\subseteq\mathcal MXâŠ†M with âˆ£Xâˆ£=k|X|=kâˆ£Xâˆ£=k. SâŠ†NS\subseteq NSâŠ†N is a blocking coalition against XXX if âˆ£Sâˆ£â‰¥âŒˆnkâŒ‰|S|\ge\lceil\frac{n}{k}\rceilâˆ£Sâˆ£â‰¥âŒˆknâ€‹âŒ‰ and âˆƒyâˆˆM\exist y\in\mathcal MâˆƒyâˆˆM s.t. âˆ€iâˆˆS,d(i,y)<Di(X)\forall i\in S,d(i,y)\lt D_i(X)âˆ€iâˆˆS,d(i,y)<Diâ€‹(X). XâŠ†NX\subseteq \mathcal NXâŠ†N is proportional if there is no blocking coalition against XXX.

é˜»å¡è”ç›Ÿï¼šå­˜åœ¨ä¸€ä¸ªå€™é€‰ä¸­å¿ƒç‚¹ yyyï¼Œå­˜åœ¨ä¸€ç»„æ•°æ®ç‚¹ SSS æ»¡è¶³å…¶ç‚¹æ•°è¦æ¯”ç°‡å¹³å‡ç‚¹æ•°å¤šï¼šä½¿å¾— SSS ä¸­ä»»æ„ä¸€ç‚¹åˆ° yyy çš„è·ç¦»ï¼Œéƒ½æ¯”è¿™ç»„æ•°æ®ç‚¹åˆ°åŸæ¥åˆ†é…çš„å¯¹åº”ç°‡ä¸­å¿ƒç‚¹çš„è·ç¦»è¿‘ã€‚

æ¯”ä¾‹å…¬å¹³ï¼šä¸€ç»„ç°‡åˆ†é…ä¸­ä¸åŒ…å«é˜»å¡è”ç›Ÿï¼Œåˆ™è¯¥ç°‡åˆ†é…æ˜¯æ¯”ä¾‹å…¬å¹³çš„ã€‚

Equivalently, XXX is proportional if âˆ€SâŠ†N\forall S \subseteq Nâˆ€SâŠ†N with âˆ£Sâˆ£â‰¥âŒˆnkâŒ‰|S| \ge\lceil\frac{n}{k}\rceilâˆ£Sâˆ£â‰¥âŒˆknâ€‹âŒ‰ and for all yâˆˆMy \in MyâˆˆM, there exists iâˆˆSi \in SiâˆˆS with d(i,y)â‰¥Di(X)d(i, y) \ge D_i(X)d(i,y)â‰¥Diâ€‹(X).

â—The quantification is over all subset of sufficient size. Do not consider a single iâˆˆSi\in SiâˆˆS and ignore all of the other points.

Advantages of PROP

  • PROP implies weak Pareto optimality: For any PROP solution XXX, there does not exist another solution Xâ€²X'Xâ€² s.t. Di(Xâ€²)<Di(X)D_i(X')\lt D_i(X)Diâ€‹(Xâ€²)<Diâ€‹(X) for all iâˆˆNi\in\mathcal NiâˆˆN.
  • Oblivious, does not depend on sensitive attribute or protected sub-groups.
  • Robust to outlier.
  • Scale invariant: a multiplicative scaling of all distances does not affect the set of PROP solution.
  • Approximately PROP can be efficiently computed.
  • Can be efficiently checked: no need to compute entire pairwise distance matrix.

However, PROP is incompatible with kkk-center, kkk-means, kkk-median in the worst case.

ğŸ“–Definition 2. XâŠ†MX\subseteq\mathcal MXâŠ†M with âˆ£Xâˆ£=k|X|=kâˆ£Xâˆ£=k is Ï\rhoÏ-approximate proportional (abbr. Ï\rhoÏ-proportional) if âˆ€SâŠ†N\forall S\subseteq\mathcal Nâˆ€SâŠ†N with âˆ£Sâˆ£>âŒˆnkâŒ‰|S|\gt\lceil\frac{n}{k}\rceilâˆ£Sâˆ£>âŒˆknâ€‹âŒ‰ and âˆ€yâˆˆM\forall y\in\mathcal Mâˆ€yâˆˆM, there exists iâˆˆSi\in SiâˆˆS with Ïâ‹…d(i,y)â‰¥Di(X)\rho\cdot d(i,y)\ge D_i(X)Ïâ‹…d(i,y)â‰¥Diâ€‹(X).

Results and Outline

Existence of PROP and its approximation

PROP clustering solution doesnâ€™t always exist.

  • Better than 222-PROP solution doesnâ€™t always exist.

A greedy algorithm yields (1+2)(1+\sqrt2)(1+2â€‹)-PROP solution in the worst case.

PROP as constraint

To optimize kkk-median objective subject to PROP constraint.

Use the rounding to find an O(1)O(1)O(1)-PROP solution to the kkk-median.

PROP and Randomness

PROP is approximately preserved if we take a random sample of the data points of size O~(k3)\tilde{O}(k^3)O~(k3).

For constant kkk, we can check if a given clustering s proportional as well as compute approximately PROP solutions in near linear time, comparable to the time for classic kkk-means heuristic.

Existence and Computation of PROP Solutions

ğŸ¤”Claim 1. For all Ï<2\rho\lt2Ï<2, a Ï\rhoÏ-PROP solution is not guaranteed to exist.

Consider instance N={ai},M={xi}\mathcal N=\{a_i\},\mathcal M=\{x_i\}N={aiâ€‹},M={xiâ€‹} with âˆ£Nâˆ£=âˆ£Mâˆ£=6,k=3|\mathcal N|=|\mathcal M|=6,k=3âˆ£Nâˆ£=âˆ£Mâˆ£=6,k=3 with distance:

x1x2x3x4x5x6
a1412âˆâˆâˆ
a2241âˆâˆâˆ
a3124âˆâˆâˆ
a4âˆâˆâˆ412
a5âˆâˆâˆ241
a6âˆâˆâˆ124

Itâ€™s easy to check that any solution can not be better than 222-PROP.

ğŸ¤”Claim 2. In case where N=M\mathcal N=\mathcal MN=M, for all Ï<1.5\rho\lt1.5Ï<1.5, a Ï\rhoÏ-PROP solution is not guaranteed to exist.

A counterexample in the paper.

Computing 2.414-PROP Clustering

Let B(x,Î´)={iâˆˆN:d(i,x)â‰¤Î´}B(x,\delta)=\{i\in\mathcal N:d(i,x)\le\delta\}B(x,Î´)={iâˆˆN:d(i,x)â‰¤Î´} (The ball of distance Î´\deltaÎ´ about center xxx).

Pseudo Code - Greedy Capture

  1. Î´â†0,Xâ†âˆ…,Nâ†N\delta\gets0,X\gets\empty,N\gets\mathcal NÎ´â†0,Xâ†âˆ…,Nâ†N
  2. while Nâ‰ âˆ…N\neq\emptyNî€ =âˆ…, do
    • Smoothly increase Î´\deltaÎ´
    • while âˆƒxâˆˆX\exist x\in XâˆƒxâˆˆX s.t. âˆ£B(x,Î´)âˆ©Nâˆ£â‰¥1|B(x,\delta)\cap N|\ge1âˆ£B(x,Î´)âˆ©Nâˆ£â‰¥1 do
      • Nâ†Nâ•²B(x,Î´)N\gets N\diagdown B(x,\delta)Nâ†Nâ•²B(x,Î´).
    • while âˆƒxâˆˆ(Mâ•²X)\exist x\in(\mathcal M\diagdown X)âˆƒxâˆˆ(Mâ•²X) s.t. âˆ£B(x,Î´)âˆ©Nâˆ£â‰¥âŒˆnkâŒ‰|B(x,\delta)\cap N|\ge\lceil\frac{n}{k}\rceilâˆ£B(x,Î´)âˆ©Nâˆ£â‰¥âŒˆknâ€‹âŒ‰ do
      • Xâ†Xâˆª{x}X\gets X\cup\{x\}Xâ†Xâˆª{x}
      • Nâ†Nâ•²B(x,Î´)N\gets N\diagdown B(x,\delta)Nâ†Nâ•²B(x,Î´)
  3. return XXX

Greedy Capture runs in O~(mn)\tilde O(mn)O~(mn) time.

The algorithm continuously grows. When the ball around a center has captured âŒˆnkâŒ‰\lceil\frac{n}{k}\rceilâŒˆknâ€‹âŒ‰ points, we open that center and disregards all of the captured points.

Difference between kkk-means and kkk-median: Balls grow around data points in kkk-median instead of centers.

ğŸ¯Theorem 1. Greedy Capture algorithm yields a (1+2)(1+\sqrt2)(1+2â€‹)-PROP clustering, and there exists an instance for which this bound is tight.

  1. XXX uses at most kkk centers, because it only opens a center when âŒˆnkâŒ‰\lceil\frac{n}{k}\rceilâŒˆknâ€‹âŒ‰ unmatched points are absorbed by the sphere. This can only happen at most kkk times.
  2. Suppose for contradiction that XXX is not (1+2)(1+\sqrt 2)(1+2â€‹)-PROP. â€¦

The example where Greedy Capture yields exactly this bound: N={a1,â‹¯â€‰,a6},M={x1,â‹¯â€‰,x4},k=3\mathcal N=\{a_1,\cdots,a_6\},\mathcal M=\{x_1,\cdots,x_4\},k=3N={a1â€‹,â‹¯,a6â€‹},M={x1â€‹,â‹¯,x4â€‹},k=3.

x1x2x3x4
a111+âˆš2âˆâˆ
a2âˆš2-11-Îµâˆâˆ
a31+âˆš21-Îµâˆâˆ
a4âˆâˆ11+âˆš2
a5âˆâˆâˆš2-11-Îµ
a6âˆâˆ1+âˆš21-Îµ
  • Greedy Capture will open x2x_2x2â€‹ and x4x_4x4â€‹. The coalition {a1,a2}\{a_1,a_2\}{a1â€‹,a2â€‹} can each reduce their distance by factor 1+21+\sqrt21+2â€‹ and Ïµâ†’0\epsilon\to0Ïµâ†’0 by deviating to x1x_1x1â€‹.

I strongly suspect that the PROP fairness notion in clustering is thought after the algorithm.ğŸ¤

â“Open Problem: Can we fill the gap between 1+21+\sqrt 21+2â€‹ and 222 by inventing new algorithm? Or can we invent a new algorithm that has a better bound than 1+21+\sqrt21+2â€‹?

Local Capture Heuristic

Local Capture heuristic produces more proportional clustering.

It takes a target value of Ï\rhoÏ as a parameter, and proceeds by iteratively finding a center that violates Ï\rhoÏ-fairness and swapping it for the center in the current solution that is least demanded.

Pseudo Code - LCH

Input: Ï\rhoÏ

  1. Initialize XXX as a random subset of kkk centers from M\mathcal MM.
  2. repeat until no changes occur:
    1. for yâˆˆMy\in\mathcal MyâˆˆM do
      • Syâ†{iâˆˆN:Ïâ‹…diy<Di(X)}S_y\gets\{i\in N:\rho\cdot d_{iy}\lt D_i(X)\}Syâ€‹â†{iâˆˆN:Ïâ‹…diyâ€‹<Diâ€‹(X)}
      • if âˆ£Syâˆ£â‰¥âŒˆnkâŒ‰|S_y|\ge\lceil\frac{n}{k}\rceilâˆ£Syâ€‹âˆ£â‰¥âŒˆknâ€‹âŒ‰ then
        • xâˆ—â†argâ¡minâ¡xâˆˆXâˆ£{iâˆˆN:dix=Di(X)}âˆ£x^*\gets\arg\min_{x\in X}|\{i\in N:d_{ix}=D_i(X)\}|xâˆ—â†argminxâˆˆXâ€‹âˆ£{iâˆˆN:dixâ€‹=Diâ€‹(X)}âˆ£
        • Xâ†(Xâ•²{xâˆ—})âˆª{y}X\gets(X\diagdown\{x^*\})\cup\{y\}Xâ†(Xâ•²{xâˆ—})âˆª{y}
  3. return XXX

LCH runs in O~(mn2)\tilde O(mn^2)O~(mn2) time. No guarantee of convergence! aka for a given Ï\rhoÏ, there may not exist a Ï\rhoÏ-proportional solution.

If LCH terminate, it must return a Ï\rhoÏ-PROP solution.

PROP as a Constraint

Problem with LCH and Greedy Capture: They may find a PROP clustering with poor global objective, even when exact PROP clustering with good global objectives exist.

A bad example: k=2k=2k=2, two easily defined clusters containing 40%,60%40\%,60\%40%,60% of the data points respectively. It is possible Greedy Capture only open one point in the larger cluster. It is PROP, but not optimized w.r.t. main object.

So we need to solve this problem by optimizing the kkk-median objective subject to PROP as a constraint.

Consider kkk-median and kkk-means.

ğŸ¯Theorem 2. There is a Ï\rhoÏ-PROP clustering with kkk-median objective ccc. In polynomial time in mmm and nnn, we can compute a O(Ï)O(\rho)O(Ï)-PROP clustering with kkk-median objective at most 8c8c8c.

We can compute a constant approximate PROP with kkk-median objective at most eight times the minimum kkk-median objective PROP clustering.

Linear Programming

The standard linear programming relaxation of the kkk-median minimization problem. Then add a constraint to encode PROP.

MinimizeÂ âˆ‘iâˆˆNâˆ‘jâˆˆMd(i,j)zijÂ Â (1)SubjectÂ toÂ âˆ‘jâˆˆMzij=1âˆ€iâˆˆNÂ Â (2)zijâ‰¤yjâˆ€jâˆˆM,âˆ€iâˆˆNÂ Â (3)âˆ‘jâˆˆMyjâ‰¤kÂ Â (4)âˆ‘jâ€²âˆˆB(j,Î³Rj)yjâ€²â‰¥1âˆ€jâˆˆMÂ Â (5)zij,yjâˆˆ[0,1]âˆ€jâˆˆM,âˆ€iâˆˆNÂ Â (6)\text{Minimize }\sum_{i\in\mathcal N}\sum_{j\in\mathcal M}d(i,j)z_{ij}\ \ (1)\\\text{Subject to }\sum_{j\in\mathcal M}z_{ij}=1\forall i\in\mathcal N\ \ (2)\\z_{ij}\le y_j\forall j\in\mathcal M,\forall i\in\mathcal N\ \ (3)\\\sum_{j\in\mathcal M}y_j\le k\ \ (4)\\\sum_{j'\in B(j,\gamma R_j)}y_{j'}\ge1\forall j\in\mathcal M\ \ (5)\\z_{ij},y_j\in[0,1]\forall j\in\mathcal M,\forall i\in\mathcal N\ \ (6)MinimizeÂ iâˆˆNâˆ‘â€‹jâˆˆMâˆ‘â€‹d(i,j)zijâ€‹Â Â (1)SubjectÂ toÂ jâˆˆMâˆ‘â€‹zijâ€‹=1âˆ€iâˆˆNÂ Â (2)zijâ€‹â‰¤yjâ€‹âˆ€jâˆˆM,âˆ€iâˆˆNÂ Â (3)jâˆˆMâˆ‘â€‹yjâ€‹â‰¤kÂ Â (4)jâ€²âˆˆB(j,Î³Rjâ€‹)âˆ‘â€‹yjâ€²â€‹â‰¥1âˆ€jâˆˆMÂ Â (5)zijâ€‹,yjâ€‹âˆˆ[0,1]âˆ€jâˆˆM,âˆ€iâˆˆNÂ Â (6)

B(j,Î³R)B(j,\gamma R)B(j,Î³R) is the ball with center jjj with radius Î³R\gamma RÎ³R.

zijz_{ij}zijâ€‹ is the indicator variable equal to 111 if iâˆˆNi\in\mathcal NiâˆˆN is matched to jâˆˆMj\in\mathcal MjâˆˆM.

yjy_jyjâ€‹ is the indicator variable equal to 111 if jâˆˆXj\in XjâˆˆX, i.e., if we want to use the center jjj in the clustering.

  • Objective (1) is the kkk-median objective.
  • Constraint (2) requires that every point must be matched.
  • Constraint (3) ensures that every points must be matched to the only center.
  • Constraint (4) allows at most kkk centers to be opened.
  • Constraint (6) relax the indicator to be real value between 000 and 111.

The elaboration of constraint (5): it approximately encodes PROP. Let RjR_jRjâ€‹ be the minimum value s.t. âˆ£B(j,Rj)âˆ£â‰¥âŒˆnkâŒ‰|B(j,R_j)|\ge\lceil\frac{n}{k}\rceilâˆ£B(j,Rjâ€‹)âˆ£â‰¥âŒˆknâ€‹âŒ‰. aka RjR_jRjâ€‹ is the distance of the âŒˆnkâŒ‰\lceil\frac{n}{k}\rceilâŒˆknâ€‹âŒ‰ farthest point in N\mathcal NN from jjj.

ğŸ¤”Lemma 1. Let XXX be a clustering, Î³â‰¥1\gamma\ge1Î³â‰¥1. If âˆ€jâˆˆM\forall j\in \mathcal Mâˆ€jâˆˆM there exists some xâˆˆXx\in XxâˆˆX s.t. d(j,x)â‰¤Î³Rjd(j,x)\le\gamma R_jd(j,x)â‰¤Î³Rjâ€‹, then XXX is (1+Î³)(1+\gamma)(1+Î³)-PROP. If XXX is Î³\gammaÎ³-PROP, then âˆ€jâˆˆM\forall j\in \mathcal Mâˆ€jâˆˆM there exists some xâˆˆXx\in XxâˆˆX s.t. d(j,x)â‰¤(1+Î³)Rjd(j,x)\le(1+\gamma)R_jd(j,x)â‰¤(1+Î³)Rjâ€‹.

Proof by contradiction and triangle inequality.

So Ï\rhoÏ-PROP clustering XXX with kkk-median objective ccc. In constraint (5) Î³=Ï+1\gamma=\rho+1Î³=Ï+1. Lemma 1 guarantees that XXX is feasible for LP.

So the fractional solution has kkk-median objective is at most ccc. Then round the resulting fractional solution. A variation of rounding algorithm preserves constraint (5).

ğŸ¤”Lemma 2. Let {yj},{zij}\{y_j\},\{z_{ij}\}{yjâ€‹},{zijâ€‹} be a fractional solution to the linear program in LP. There is an integer solution {y^j},{z^ij}\{\hat y_j\},\{\hat z_{ij}\}{y^â€‹jâ€‹},{z^ijâ€‹} that is 888-approximation to the objective, and that opens kkk centers. Furthermore, for all jâˆˆMj\in\mathcal MjâˆˆM, âˆ‘jâ€²âˆˆB(j,27Î³Rj)y^jâ€²â‰¥1\sum_{j'\in B(j,27\gamma R_j)}\hat y_{j'}\ge1âˆ‘jâ€²âˆˆB(j,27Î³Rjâ€‹)â€‹y^â€‹jâ€²â€‹â‰¥1.

Lemma 1 + 2 implies result of the rounding (27(1+Ï)+1)(27(1+\rho)+1)(27(1+Ï)+1)-PROP, by setting Î³=1+Ï\gamma=1+\rhoÎ³=1+Ï. Since kkk-median objective of the fractional solution is at most ccc, kkk-median objective of the rounded solution is at most 8c8c8c by proof. The factor 272727 can be improved to 131313 in the special case where N=M\mathcal N=\mathcal MN=M.

Proof of Lemma 2

Argument is to show that with constraint (5), after rounding, the results is still approximately satisfied.

Given a fractional solution to the linear program as {yj},{zij}\{y_j\},\{z_{ij}\}{yjâ€‹},{zijâ€‹}, let CË‰i=âˆ‘jâˆˆMd(i,j)zij\bar C_i=\sum_{j\in\mathcal M}d(i,j)z_{ij}CË‰iâ€‹=âˆ‘jâˆˆMâ€‹d(i,j)zijâ€‹ aka contribution of point iii to the kkk-median objective in the fractional optimum.

  • Step 1: Consolidate all demands tit_itiâ€‹ (for all points it is set to 111) to obtain {tiâ€²}\{t_i'\}{tiâ€²â€‹} s.t. âˆ€i,jâˆˆM\forall i,j\in\mathcal Mâˆ€i,jâˆˆM with tiâ€²,tjâ€²>0t_i',t_j'\gt0tiâ€²â€‹,tjâ€²â€‹>0, they must be sufficiently far away s.t. cij>4maxâ¡(CË‰i,CË‰j)c_{ij}\gt4\max(\bar C_i,\bar C_j)cijâ€‹>4max(CË‰iâ€‹,CË‰jâ€‹). Let Mâ€²\mathcal M'Mâ€² be the set of centers with positive demand after this step, i.e., Mâ€²={jâˆˆM:tjâ€²>0}\mathcal M'=\{j\in\mathcal M:t_j'\gt0\}Mâ€²={jâˆˆM:tjâ€²â€‹>0}.
  • Step 2a: Consolidate open centers by moving each center not in Mâ€²\mathcal M'Mâ€² to the nearest center in Mâ€²\mathcal M'Mâ€².
  • Step 2b: â€¦
  • â€¦

Very complex.

Sampling for Linear-Time Implementations and Auditing

PROP under uniform random sampling.

Draw âˆ£Nâˆ£|N|âˆ£Nâˆ£ individuals independent and identically distributed from the uniform distribution on N\mathcal NN.

This paper shows that PROP is well preserved under random sampling.

PROP Under Random Sampling

For any XâŠ†MX\subseteq\mathcal MXâŠ†M of size kkk and center yâˆˆMy\in\mathcal MyâˆˆM, define R(N,X,y)={iâˆˆN:Di(X)>Ïâ‹…d(i,y)}R(\mathcal N,X,y)=\{i\in\mathcal N:D_i(X)\gt\rho\cdot d(i,y)\}R(N,X,y)={iâˆˆN:Diâ€‹(X)>Ïâ‹…d(i,y)}. Note that XXX is not Ï\rhoÏ-PROP w.r.t. N\mathcal NN iff there is some yâˆˆMy\in\mathcal MyâˆˆM s.t. âˆ£R(N,X,y)âˆ£âˆ£Nâˆ£â‰¥1k\frac{|R(\mathcal N,X,y)|}{|\mathcal N|}\ge\frac{1}{k}âˆ£Nâˆ£âˆ£R(N,X,y)âˆ£â€‹â‰¥k1â€‹.

A random sample approximately preserves this fraction for all solution XXX and deviating centers yyy.

Proof sketch: we take a union bound over all possible solutions and deviations, and there are only kâ‹…Cmkk\cdot C_m^kkâ‹…Cmkâ€‹ such combinations.

ğŸ¤”ğŸ¯Theorem 3. Given N,M\mathcal N,\mathcal MN,M and parameter Ïâ‰¥1\rho\ge1Ïâ‰¥1, fix parameters Ïµ,Î´âˆˆ[0,1]\epsilon,\delta\in[0,1]Ïµ,Î´âˆˆ[0,1]. Let NâŠ†NN\subseteq\mathcal NNâŠ†N of size Î©(k3Ïµ2logâ¡mÎ´)\Omega(\frac{k^3}{\epsilon^2}\log\frac{m}{\delta})Î©(Ïµ2k3â€‹logÎ´mâ€‹) be chosen uniformly at random. Then, with probability at least 1âˆ’Î´1-\delta1âˆ’Î´, the following holds for all (X,y)(X,y)(X,y):

âˆ£âˆ£R(N,X,y)âˆ£âˆ£Nâˆ£âˆ’âˆ£R(N,X,y)âˆ£âˆ£Nâˆ£âˆ£â‰¤Ïµk\left\vert\frac{\vert R(N,X,y)\vert}{\vert N\vert}-\frac{\vert R(\mathcal N,X,y)\vert}{\vert\mathcal N\vert}\right\vert\le\frac{\epsilon}{k}âˆ£âˆ£âˆ£âˆ£âˆ£â€‹âˆ£Nâˆ£âˆ£R(N,X,y)âˆ£â€‹âˆ’âˆ£Nâˆ£âˆ£R(N,X,y)âˆ£â€‹âˆ£âˆ£âˆ£âˆ£âˆ£â€‹â‰¤kÏµâ€‹

å·²ç»å¯¹ 1âˆ’Î´1-\delta1âˆ’Î´ï¼ŒO/Î©(1Ïµlogâ¡1Î´)O/\Omega(\frac{1}{\epsilon}\log\frac{1}{\delta})O/Î©(Ïµ1â€‹logÎ´1â€‹), Chernoff, Hoeffding è¿™æ ·çš„ä¸œè¥¿ PTSD äº†è°¢è°¢

NNN is a random sample of N\mathcal NN. Hoeffdingâ€™s inequality implies that for any fixed (X,y)(X,y)(X,y), a sample of size âˆ£Nâˆ£=O(1Ïµ^2logâ¡1Î´^)|N|=O(\frac{1}{\hat\epsilon^2}\log\frac{1}{\hat\delta})âˆ£Nâˆ£=O(Ïµ^21â€‹logÎ´^1â€‹) is sufficient to achieve

âˆ£âˆ£R(N,X,y)âˆ£âˆ£Nâˆ£âˆ’âˆ£R(N,X,y)âˆ£âˆ£Nâˆ£âˆ£â‰¤Ïµ^\left\vert\frac{\vert R(N,X,y)\vert}{\vert N\vert}-\frac{\vert R(\mathcal N,X,y)\vert}{\vert\mathcal N\vert}\right\vert\le\hat\epsilonâˆ£âˆ£âˆ£âˆ£âˆ£â€‹âˆ£Nâˆ£âˆ£R(N,X,y)âˆ£â€‹âˆ’âˆ£Nâˆ£âˆ£R(N,X,y)âˆ£â€‹âˆ£âˆ£âˆ£âˆ£âˆ£â€‹â‰¤Ïµ^

with probability at least 1âˆ’Î´^1-\hat\delta1âˆ’Î´^. Note that there are q=mâ‹…Cmkq=m\cdot C_m^kq=mâ‹…Cmkâ€‹ possible choice of (X,y)(X,y)(X,y) over which we take the union bound. Setting Î´=Î´^q,Ïµ=Ïµ^k\delta=\frac{\hat\delta}{q},\epsilon=\frac{\hat\epsilon}{k}Î´=qÎ´^â€‹,Ïµ=kÏµ^â€‹ is sufficient for the union bound to yield the theorem.

We say solution XXX is Ï\rhoÏ-PROP to (1+Ïµ)(1+\epsilon)(1+Ïµ)-deviations if for all yâˆˆMy\in\mathcal MyâˆˆM and for all SâŠ†NS\subseteq\mathcal NSâŠ†N where âˆ£Sâˆ£â‰¥(1+Ïµ)nk|S|\ge(1+\epsilon)\frac{n}{k}âˆ£Sâˆ£â‰¥(1+Ïµ)knâ€‹, there exists some iâˆˆSi\in SiâˆˆS s.t. Ïâ‹…d(i,y)â‰¥Di(X)\rho\cdot d(i,y)\ge D_i(X)Ïâ‹…d(i,y)â‰¥Diâ€‹(X). Note that if XXX is Ï\rhoÏ-PROP to 111-deviation, it is simply Ï\rhoÏ-PROP.

ğŸ¤”Corollary 1. Let NâŠ‚NN\subset\mathcal NNâŠ‚N be a uniform random sample of size âˆ£Nâˆ£=Î©(k3Ïµ2lnâ¡mÎ´)|N|=\Omega(\frac{k^3}{\epsilon^2}\ln\frac{m}{\delta})âˆ£Nâˆ£=Î©(Ïµ2k3â€‹lnÎ´mâ€‹). Suppose XâŠ†MX\subseteq MXâŠ†M with âˆ£Xâˆ£=k|X|=kâˆ£Xâˆ£=k is Ï\rhoÏ-PROP w.r.t. NNN. Then with probability at least 1âˆ’Î´1-\delta1âˆ’Î´, XXX is Ï\rhoÏ-PROP to (1+Ïµ)(1+\epsilon)(1+Ïµ)-deviations w.r.t. N\mathcal NN.

Linear Time Implementation

We can approximately implement Greedy Capture in nearly linear time, comparable to the running time of the standard kkk-means heuristic.

ğŸ¤”Corollary 2. Greedy Capture, when run on M\mathcal MM and a random sample NâŠ†NN\subseteq\mathcal NNâŠ†N of size âˆ£Nâˆ£=Î˜~(k3Ïµ2)|N|=\tilde\Theta(\frac{k^3}{\epsilon^2})âˆ£Nâˆ£=Î˜~(Ïµ2k3â€‹), provides a solution that is (1+2)(1+\sqrt 2)(1+2â€‹)-PROP to (1+Ïµ)(1+\epsilon)(1+Ïµ)-deviation with high probability in O~(k3Ïµ2m)\tilde O(\frac{k^3}{\epsilon^2}m)O~(Ïµ2k3â€‹m) time.

There are similar speedup for Local Capture algorithm.

Efficient Auditing

Audit Problem: To answer whether a solution produced happens to be proportional.

Given N,M\mathcal N,\mathcal MN,M, XâŠ‚NX\subset \mathcal NXâŠ‚N with âˆ£Xâˆ£<k|X|\lt kâˆ£Xâˆ£<k, find the minimum value of Ï\rhoÏ s.t. XXX is Ï\rhoÏ-PROP.

Trivial idea: One can solve the audit problem exactly in O((k+m)n)O((k+m)n)O((k+m)n) time by computing for each yâˆˆMy\in\mathcal MyâˆˆM, the quantity Ïy\rho_yÏyâ€‹, the âŒˆnkâŒ‰\lceil\frac{n}{k}\rceilâŒˆknâ€‹âŒ‰ largest value of Di(X)d(i,y)\frac{D_i(X)}{d(i,y)}d(i,y)Diâ€‹(X)â€‹. Then find the yyy that maximizes Ïy\rho_yÏyâ€‹. Again, this takes quadratic time, which can be worse than the time taken to find the clustering itself.

(Ïµ,Î´)(\epsilon,\delta)(Ïµ,Î´)-Audit Problem: Find the minimum value of Ï\rhoÏ s.t. XXX is Ï\rhoÏ-PROP to (1+Ïµ)(1+\epsilon)(1+Ïµ)-deviations with probability at least 1âˆ’Î´1-\delta1âˆ’Î´. This problem can be efficiently solved by using a random sample NâŠ†NN\subseteq\mathcal NNâŠ†N of points to conduct the audit.

ğŸ¤”Corollary 3. The (Ïµ,Î´)(\epsilon,\delta)(Ïµ,Î´)-Audit Problem can be solved in O~((k+m)k3Ïµ2)\tilde O((k+m)\frac{k^3}{\epsilon^2})O~((k+m)Ïµ2k3â€‹) time.

Implementation and Empirical Results

Highly depends on which dataset.

Conclusion and Open Problems

The exact PROP may not exist.

Efficient algorithms for computing approximate PROP solutions.

Constrained optimization and sampling for further applications.

Finally, PROP on real data: data dependent trade-off between PROP and kkk-means objective.

Open Problems

â“Can we close the approximate factor gap between 222 and 1+21+\sqrt21+2â€‹?

â“Is there a more efficient and easily explainable algorithm for optimizing total cost subject to PROP?

â“Is there any other fair solution concepts for clustering?

â“Can the idea of PROP as a group fairness concept be adapted for supervised learning tasks like classification and regression?

Bonus: Trying to break the 1+21+\sqrt21+2â€‹ barrier

Look at the example for 1+21+\sqrt 21+2â€‹ lower bound by applying Greedy Capture.

Letâ€™s look at the half.

a1a2a3
x11112âˆ’1\sqrt2-12â€‹âˆ’11+21+\sqrt21+2â€‹
x21+21+\sqrt21+2â€‹1âˆ’Ïµ1-\epsilon1âˆ’Ïµ1âˆ’Ïµ1-\epsilon1âˆ’Ïµ

The reason why this is (1+2)(1+\sqrt2)(1+2â€‹)-PROP is that x2x_2x2â€‹ clinches a2,a3a_2,a_3a2â€‹,a3â€‹ prior to x1x_1x1â€‹.

But if we choose x1x_1x1â€‹ as clustering center, the clustering will become PROP!

Now consider some modification on Greedy Capture, making it better approximation for PROP.

Pseudo Code for â€œAdvancedâ€ Greedy Capture

Input: k,N,Mk,\mathcal N,\mathcal Mk,N,M.

Output: a set of XXX containing at most kkk cluster centers.

  1. Î”jâ†0âˆ€jâˆˆM\Delta_j\gets0\forall j\in\mathcal MÎ”jâ€‹â†0âˆ€jâˆˆM
  2. Xâ†âˆ…,Nâ†N,Câ†âˆ…X\gets\empty,N\gets\mathcal N,C\gets\emptyXâ†âˆ…,Nâ†N,Câ†âˆ…
  3. While Nâ‰ âˆ…N\neq\emptyNî€ =âˆ… do
    1. Let iâˆˆM,xâˆˆNâ•²Ci\in\mathcal M,x\in N\diagdown CiâˆˆM,xâˆˆNâ•²C s.t. d(i,x)âˆ’Î”id(i,x)-\Delta_id(i,x)âˆ’Î”iâ€‹ is minimum
    2. Î”iâ†d(i,x)\Delta_i\gets d(i,x)Î”iâ€‹â†d(i,x)
    3. Câ†Câˆª{x}C\gets C\cup\{x\}Câ†Câˆª{x}
    4. If iâˆˆXi\in XiâˆˆX then
      • Nâ†Nâ•²{x}N\gets N\diagdown\{x\}Nâ†Nâ•²{x}
    5. else if iâˆˆMâ•²Xi\in\mathcal M\diagdown XiâˆˆMâ•²X and âˆ£B(i,Î”i)âˆ©Câˆ©Nâˆ£=âŒˆn/kâŒ‰|B(i,\Delta_i)\cap C\cap N|=\lceil n/k\rceilâˆ£B(i,Î”iâ€‹)âˆ©Câˆ©Nâˆ£=âŒˆn/kâŒ‰ then
      • Xâ†Xâˆª{x}X\gets X\cup\{x\}Xâ†Xâˆª{x}
      • Nâ†Nâ•²(B(i,Î”i)âˆ©C)N\gets N\diagdown (B(i,\Delta_i)\cap C)Nâ†Nâ•²(B(i,Î”iâ€‹)âˆ©C)
  4. return XXX

On the (1+2)(1+\sqrt 2)(1+2â€‹)-PROP example, this â€œAdvancedâ€ Greedy Capture computes a exactly PROP clustering.

On the 222-PROP example, this algorithm computes 222-PROP clustering.

Now we havenâ€™t prove the correctness of this algorithm.

Does this algorithm guarantees the lower bound of 222?
entry.summary: Read the paper Proportionally Fair Clustering by Chen et al.

entry.content:
Parity function is not in AC0AC^0AC0.

MAJâˆˆÌ¸AC0MAJ\not\in AC^0MAJî€ âˆˆAC0.

NEXPâŠ†Ì¸ACC0NEXP\not\subseteq ACC^0NEXPî€ âŠ†ACC0.

Some unknown proposition:

  • whether NPâŠ†ACC0NP\subseteq ACC^0NPâŠ†ACC0.

  • whether EXPâŠ†ACC0EXP\subseteq ACC^0EXPâŠ†ACC0.

  • whether NEXPâŠ†TC0NEXP\subseteq TC^0NEXPâŠ†TC0.

  • whether all languages in NEXPNEXPNEXP can be computed by depth 222 circuits consisting of weighted linear threshold gates.

The Razborov-Smolensky Lower Bound

The lower bounds for class AC0[pr]AC^0[p^r]AC0[pr], where ppp is a prime.

Main idea: convert Boolean circuit of small size into a low-degree probabilistic polynomial.

Here we consider r=1r=1r=1.

ğŸ“–Definition 43. Let F\mathbb FF be a field. By a probabilistic polynomial PPP in nnn variables of total degree ddd over F\mathbb FF we mean a random variable assuming as value such polynomials. Let f:{0,1}nâ†’{0,1}f:\{0,1\}^n\to\{0,1\}f:{0,1}nâ†’{0,1} be a Boolean function. We say that PPP computes fff with error Ïµ\epsilonÏµ if Prâ¡[P(x)=f(x)]â‰¥1âˆ’Ïµ\Pr[P(x)=f(x)]\ge1-\epsilonPr[P(x)=f(x)]â‰¥1âˆ’Ïµ for all xâˆˆ{0,1}nx\in\{0,1\}^nxâˆˆ{0,1}n. Similarly we say that PPP computes fff with one-sided error Ïµ\epsilonÏµ if PPP computes fff with error Ïµ\epsilonÏµ and furthermore we have Prâ¡[P(x)=f(x)]=1\Pr[P(x)=f(x)]=1Pr[P(x)=f(x)]=1 for all xâˆˆ{0,1}nx\in\{0,1\}^nxâˆˆ{0,1}n where f(x)=0f(x)=0f(x)=0.

Then construct a probabilistic polynomial form an AC0[p]AC^0[p]AC0[p] circuit.

ğŸ¤”Lemma 13. Let ppp be a prime and let CCC be a depth hhh circuit with at most SSS unbounded fanin AND,OR,MODpAND,OR,MOD_pAND,OR,MODpâ€‹ as well as negation gates computing a Boolean function fff. Let tâ‰¥1t\ge1tâ‰¥1 be an arbitrary integer. Then for any nnn there exist a probabilistic polynomial in nnn variables of total degree at most (pt)h(pt)^h(pt)h over Zp\mathbb Z_pZpâ€‹ computing fff with error Spt\frac{S}{p^t}ptSâ€‹.

Probabilistic polynomial for each of the gates of CCC. Each of these will be of degree at most ptptpt and compute the gate function with error 1pt\frac{1}{p^t}pt1â€‹.

Composing these will give probabilistic polynomial of degree at most (pt)h(pt)^h(pt)h computing fff and with error at most Spt\frac{S}{p^t}ptSâ€‹ by a union bound.

Input gates: xix_ixiâ€‹ can be computed by the polynomials xix_ixiâ€‹ with error 000. xË‰i\bar x_ixË‰iâ€‹ can be computed by the polynomials 1âˆ’xi1-x_i1âˆ’xiâ€‹ with error 000.

Negation gates: Â¬z\neg zÂ¬z can be computed by the polynomial 1âˆ’y1-y1âˆ’y with error 000.

MODpMOD_pMODpâ€‹ gate with inputs z1,â‹¯â€‰,zkz_1,\cdots,z_kz1â€‹,â‹¯,zkâ€‹ can be computed by the polynomial

(âˆ‘i=1kzi)pâˆ’1\left(\sum_{i=1}^kz_i\right)^{p-1}(i=1âˆ‘kâ€‹ziâ€‹)pâˆ’1

with error 000 by Fermatâ€™s little theorem.

OROROR gate with inputs z1,â‹¯â€‰,zkz_1,\cdots,z_kz1â€‹,â‹¯,zkâ€‹: Consider picking a1,â‹¯â€‰,akâˆˆZpa_1,\cdots,a_k\in\mathbb Z_pa1â€‹,â‹¯,akâ€‹âˆˆZpâ€‹ uniformly and independently at random. Using Fermatâ€™s little theorem again, we have the polynomial

(âˆ‘i=1kaizi)pâˆ’1\left(\sum_{i=1}^ka_iz_i\right)^{p-1}(i=1âˆ‘kâ€‹aiâ€‹ziâ€‹)pâˆ’1

computes OR(z1,â‹¯â€‰,zk)OR(z_1,\cdots,z_k)OR(z1â€‹,â‹¯,zkâ€‹) with one-sided error 1p\frac{1}{p}p1â€‹. In order to decrease the error, use success amplification using ttt independent trials.

1âˆ’âˆj=1t(1âˆ’(âˆ‘i=1kaijzi)pâˆ’1),1-\prod_{j=1}^t\left(1-\left(\sum_{i=1}^ka_{ij}z_i\right)^{p-1}\right),1âˆ’j=1âˆtâ€‹ââ›â€‹1âˆ’(i=1âˆ‘kâ€‹aijâ€‹ziâ€‹)pâˆ’1â ââ€‹,

which then computes OR(z1,â‹¯â€‰,zk)OR(z_1,\cdots,z_k)OR(z1â€‹,â‹¯,zkâ€‹) with one-sided error 1pt\frac{1}{p^t}pt1â€‹.

Analogously, for ANDANDAND gate, the probabilistic polynomial

1âˆ’âˆj=1t(1âˆ’(âˆ‘i=1kaij(1âˆ’zi))pâˆ’1).1-\prod_{j=1}^t\left(1-\left(\sum_{i=1}^ka_{ij}(1-z_i)\right)^{p-1}\right).1âˆ’j=1âˆtâ€‹ââ›â€‹1âˆ’(i=1âˆ‘kâ€‹aijâ€‹(1âˆ’ziâ€‹))pâˆ’1â ââ€‹.

ğŸ¤”Lemma 14. Let PPP be a probabilistic polynomial of degree ddd and let f:{a,b}nâ†’Ff:\{a,b\}^n\to\mathbb Ff:{a,b}nâ†’F be a function s.t. Prâ¡[P(x)=f(x)]â‰¥1âˆ’Ïµ\Pr[P(x)=f(x)]\ge1-\epsilonPr[P(x)=f(x)]â‰¥1âˆ’Ïµ. Then there exists a polynomial Pâ€²P'Pâ€² of degree ddd and a set GâŠ†{a,b}nG\subseteq\{a,b\}^nGâŠ†{a,b}n with âˆ£Gâˆ£â‰¥(1âˆ’Ïµ)2n|G|\ge(1-\epsilon)2^nâˆ£Gâˆ£â‰¥(1âˆ’Ïµ)2n s.t. P(x)=f(x)P(x)=f(x)P(x)=f(x) for all xâˆˆGx\in GxâˆˆG.

Linearity of expectation:

E[âˆ£xâˆˆ{a,b}n:P(x)=f(x)âˆ£]=âˆ‘xâˆˆ{a,b}nPrâ¡[P(x)=f(x)]â‰¥2n(1âˆ’Ïµ),\mathbb E[|x\in\{a,b\}^n:P(x)=f(x)|]=\sum_{x\in\{a,b\}^n}\Pr[P(x)=f(x)]\ge2^n(1-\epsilon),E[âˆ£xâˆˆ{a,b}n:P(x)=f(x)âˆ£]=xâˆˆ{a,b}nâˆ‘â€‹Pr[P(x)=f(x)]â‰¥2n(1âˆ’Ïµ),

A low-degree polynomial is equal to the product of all variables on a set GâŠ†{a,b}nG\subseteq\{a,b\}^nGâŠ†{a,b}n enables one to replace all polynomials by equivalent polynomials on the set GGG of degree significantly smaller than nnn.

ğŸ¤”Lemma 15. Let PPP be a polynomial in nnn variables of total degree Î”\DeltaÎ” over a field F\mathbb FF. Let a,bâˆˆFa,b\in\mathbb Fa,bâˆˆF and suppose GâŠ†{a,b}nG\subseteq\{a,b\}^nGâŠ†{a,b}n is s.t.

âˆ€yâˆˆG:P(y)=âˆi=1nyi.\forall y\in G:P(y)=\prod_{i=1}^ny_i.âˆ€yâˆˆG:P(y)=i=1âˆnâ€‹yiâ€‹.

Then for every function f:Gâ†’Ff:G\to\mathbb Ff:Gâ†’F there exists a polynomial PfP_fPfâ€‹ of total degree at most n+Î”2\frac{n+\Delta}{2}2n+Î”â€‹ s.t.

âˆ€yâˆˆG:Pf(y)=f(y).\forall y\in G:P_f(y)=f(y).âˆ€yâˆˆG:Pfâ€‹(y)=f(y).

Let f:Gâ†’Ff:G\to\mathbb Ff:Gâ†’F be any function. Define multilinear polynomial QfQ_fQfâ€‹:

Qf(y)=âˆ‘xâˆˆG(f(x)(âˆi:xi=abâˆ’yibâˆ’a)(âˆi:xi=baâˆ’yiaâˆ’b)).Q_f(y)=\sum_{x\in G}\left(f(x)\left(\prod_{i:x_i=a}\frac{b-y_i}{b-a}\right)\left(\prod_{i:x_i=b}\frac{a-y_i}{a-b}\right)\right).Qfâ€‹(y)=xâˆˆGâˆ‘â€‹(f(x)(i:xiâ€‹=aâˆâ€‹bâˆ’abâˆ’yiâ€‹â€‹)(i:xiâ€‹=bâˆâ€‹aâˆ’baâˆ’yiâ€‹â€‹)).

Clearly, Qf(y)=f(y)âˆ€yâˆˆGQ_f(y)=f(y)\forall y\in GQfâ€‹(y)=f(y)âˆ€yâˆˆG. Using PPP, any monomial of degree ddd can be replaced by an equivalent polynomial of degree nâˆ’d+Î”n-d+\Deltanâˆ’d+Î” since

âˆiâˆˆIyi=(âˆi=1nyi)(âˆiâˆˆÌ¸I1yi)=P(y)âˆiâˆˆÌ¸I(1abâˆ’yibâˆ’a+1baâˆ’yiaâˆ’b).\prod_{i\in I}y_i=\left(\prod_{i=1}^ny_i\right)\left(\prod_{i\not\in I}\frac{1}{y_i}\right)=P(y)\prod_{i\not\in I}\left(\frac{1}{a}\frac{b-y_i}{b-a}+\frac{1}{b}\frac{a-y_i}{a-b}\right).iâˆˆIâˆâ€‹yiâ€‹=(i=1âˆnâ€‹yiâ€‹)ââ›â€‹iî€ âˆˆIâˆâ€‹yiâ€‹1â€‹â ââ€‹=P(y)iî€ âˆˆIâˆâ€‹(a1â€‹bâˆ’abâˆ’yiâ€‹â€‹+b1â€‹aâˆ’baâˆ’yiâ€‹â€‹).

Thus we replace each monomial of QfQ_fQfâ€‹ of degree d>n+Î”2d\gt\frac{n+\Delta}{2}d>2n+Î”â€‹ by an equivalent polynomial of degree nâˆ’d+Î”<n+Î”2n-d+\Delta\lt\frac{n+\Delta}{2}nâˆ’d+Î”<2n+Î”â€‹. We can thus take PfP_fPfâ€‹ to be the sum of these together with the monomials of QfQ_fQfâ€‹ degree at most n+Î”2\frac{n+\Delta}{2}2n+Î”â€‹.

One may convert any polynomial into a multi-linear polynomial of the same degree which is equivalent on a given hypercube {a,b}n\{a,b\}^n{a,b}n.

ğŸ¤”Lemma 16. Let a,bâˆˆFa,b\in\mathbb Fa,bâˆˆF and let PPP be a polynomial of degree ddd. Then there exists a multi-linear polynomial Pâ€²P'Pâ€² of degree at most ddd s.t. P(x)=Pâ€²(x)P(x)=P'(x)P(x)=Pâ€²(x) for all xâˆˆ{a,b}nx\in\{a,b\}^nxâˆˆ{a,b}n.

An occurrence of xikx_i^kxikâ€‹ in PPP may be replaced by the polynomial

xiâˆ’baâˆ’bak+xiâˆ’abâˆ’abk,\frac{x_i-b}{a-b}a^k+\frac{x_i-a}{b-a}b^k,aâˆ’bxiâ€‹âˆ’bâ€‹ak+bâˆ’axiâ€‹âˆ’aâ€‹bk,

which can never increase the degree.

ğŸ¤”Lemma 17. For all integers nâ‰¥1n\ge 1nâ‰¥1:

4nÏ€(n+1)â‰¤C2nnâ‰¤4nÏ€n\frac{4^n}{\sqrt{\pi(n+1)}}\le C_{2n}^n\le\frac{4^n}{\sqrt{\pi n}}Ï€(n+1)â€‹4nâ€‹â‰¤C2nnâ€‹â‰¤Ï€nâ€‹4nâ€‹

ğŸ¤”Corollary 10. For all integers nâ‰¥1n\ge1nâ‰¥1:

CâŒˆn/2âŒ‰nâ‰¤2nÏ€âŒˆn/2âŒ‰.C_{\lceil n/2\rceil}^n\le\frac{2^n}{\sqrt{\pi\lceil n/2\rceil}}.CâŒˆn/2âŒ‰nâ€‹â‰¤Ï€âŒˆn/2âŒ‰â€‹2nâ€‹.

ğŸ¤”Proposition 13. Let PPP be a polynomial in nnn variables of total degree Î”\DeltaÎ” over a field F\mathbb FF. Let a,bâˆˆFa,b\in\mathbb Fa,bâˆˆF and suppose GâŠ†{a,b}nG\subseteq \{a,b\}^nGâŠ†{a,b}n is s.t.

yâˆˆG:P(y)=âˆi=1nyi.y\in G:P(y)=\prod_{i=1}^ny_i.yâˆˆG:P(y)=i=1âˆnâ€‹yiâ€‹.

Then

âˆ£Gâˆ£â‰¤2n(12+410Î”n).|G|\le 2^n\left(\frac{1}{2}+\frac{4}{10}\frac{\Delta}{\sqrt n}\right).âˆ£Gâˆ£â‰¤2n(21â€‹+104â€‹nâ€‹Î”â€‹).

By Lemma 16, assume that PPP is multilinear.

The number of functions f:Gâ†’Ff:G\to\mathbb Ff:Gâ†’F, which amounts to pâˆ£Gâˆ£p^{|G|}pâˆ£Gâˆ£, must be less than the number of multilinear polynomials of degree at most n+Î”2\frac{n+\Delta}{2}2n+Î”â€‹, which amounts to pMp^MpM, where MMM denotes the number of monomials on nnn variables of degree at most n+Î”2\frac{n+\Delta}{2}2n+Î”â€‹. It follows that âˆ£Gâˆ£â‰¤M|G|\le Mâˆ£Gâˆ£â‰¤M.

Then conclude by estimating MMM.

M=âˆ‘i=0âŒŠn+Î”2âŒ‹Cni=2nâˆ’1+âˆ‘i=âŒˆn/2âŒ‰âŒŠn+Î”2âŒ‹Cniâ‰¤2nâˆ’1+Î”22nÏ€n/2â‰¤2nâˆ’1+410Î”2nn,M=\sum_{i=0}^{\lfloor\frac{n+\Delta}{2}\rfloor}C_n^i=2^{n-1}+\sum_{i=\lceil n/2\rceil}^{\lfloor\frac{n+\Delta}{2}\rfloor}C_n^i\le2^{n-1}+\frac{\Delta}{2}\frac{2^n}{\sqrt{\pi n/2}}\le 2^{n-1}+\frac{4}{10}\frac{\Delta2^n}{\sqrt n},M=i=0âˆ‘âŒŠ2n+Î”â€‹âŒ‹â€‹Cniâ€‹=2nâˆ’1+i=âŒˆn/2âŒ‰âˆ‘âŒŠ2n+Î”â€‹âŒ‹â€‹Cniâ€‹â‰¤2nâˆ’1+2Î”â€‹Ï€n/2â€‹2nâ€‹â‰¤2nâˆ’1+104â€‹nâ€‹Î”2nâ€‹,

where CniC_n^iCniâ€‹ is estimated by central binomial coefficient, for i>n/2i\gt n/2i>n/2, and use 2Ï€â‰¥104\sqrt{2\pi}\ge\frac{10}{4}2Ï€â€‹â‰¥410â€‹,

entry.title: Efficient ReliK 3 Parallel For Loop
entry.content:
This week, I am mainly working on parallelization of enumerating xhâ€²râ€²tâ€²x_{h'r't'}xhâ€²râ€²tâ€²â€‹: for u,v in nx.DiGraph(M).subgraph(subgraph).edges().

Target Code

ğŸ˜­First Try: ThreadPoolExecutor

On Countries, for each subgraph it takes around 3000 ms, while on SmallcodeX, it takes around 120 s per subgraph.

ResultğŸ˜©

This approach is definitely negative optimization.

âŒABORTED.

ğŸ˜­Second Try: Parallelization on GPU

Then try to do parallelization using PyTorch + CUDA.

ResultğŸ˜¢

However, it seems that there is no speed up in the experiment, for some different num_parallel values. I suspect that it is executed sequentially. Maybe I have not thoroughly understood the code.

ğŸ˜ƒThird Try: multiprocessing

Idea is straight forward.

I have num_processors processors. Then I partition the edges list(nx.DiGraph(M).subgraph(subgraph).edges()) into num_processors parts.

Each processor is responsible for a corresponding part.

I need to write the method process_edges_partition outside to process each part.

ExperimentğŸ¤©

I ran experiment on dataset Countries and CodexSmall respectively.

We want to speed up the process for calculating ReliK scores.

Setting

Set num_processors = 10;

Using TransE embeddings.

Dataset - Countries

python experiment_controller.py -d Countries -e TransE -t ReliK

For raw implementation, it takes around 470 seconds.

For multiprocessing optimization, it takes around 123 seconds.

Speedup: Around 3.8x

Dataset - CodexSmall

python experiment_controller.py -d CodexSmall -e TransE -t ReliK

For raw implementation, it takes around 12900 seconds = 215 minutes â‰ˆ 3.58 hours.

For multiprocessing optimization, it takes around 1610 second â‰ˆ26.8 minutesâ—ğŸ‘

Speedup: Around 8.0x

Staying up debugging until 2:30 a.m. finally paid off.ğŸ˜
