entry.title: Fair AI/ML 1 Core-Stability Federated Learning
entry.content:
I will begin a new project work 24 Fall: FAIRNESS IN AI/ML THROUGH THE LENS OF SOCIAL CHOICE

The basic outline is following Tutorial: Fairness in AI/ML via Social Choice by Evi Micha & Nisarg Shah in EC 2024.

The first paper I have read in last semester, Fairness in Federated Learning via Core-Stability, which was one of the possible topics.

Brief notes is here.

I will try to understand some mathematical proof in this semester.

Core-Stability

Revisit the definition of Core-Stability: A predictor Î¸âˆˆP\theta\in PÎ¸âˆˆP is called core stable if there exist no other Î¸â€²âˆˆP\theta'\in PÎ¸â€²âˆˆP and no subset SSS of agents, s.t. âˆ£Sâˆ£nui(Î¸â€²)â‰¥ui(Î¸)\frac{|S|}{n}u_i(\theta')\ge u_i(\theta)nâˆ£Sâˆ£â€‹uiâ€‹(Î¸â€²)â‰¥uiâ€‹(Î¸) for all iâˆˆSi\in SiâˆˆS, with at least one strict inequality.

âš ï¸âš ï¸âš ï¸What is WRONG with the claim

Setting S=[n]S=[n]S=[n] in definition, there is no predictor Î¸â€²âˆˆP\theta'\in PÎ¸â€²âˆˆP where âˆ‘iâˆˆ[n]ui(Î¸â€²)ui(Î¸)>n\sum_{i\in[n]}\frac{u_i(\theta')}{u_i(\theta)}\gt nâˆ‘iâˆˆ[n]â€‹uiâ€‹(Î¸)uiâ€‹(Î¸â€²)â€‹>n.

According to the definition, when we plug in S=[n]S=[n]S=[n], there exist no Î¸â€²âˆˆP\theta'\in PÎ¸â€²âˆˆP s.t.

ui(Î¸â€²)â‰¥ui(Î¸)âˆ€iâˆˆSâ‡”ui(Î¸â€²)ui(Î¸)â‰¥1âˆ€iâˆˆSu_i(\theta')\ge u_i(\theta)\forall i\in S\\\Lrarr\frac{u_i(\theta')}{u_i(\theta)}\ge 1\forall i\in Suiâ€‹(Î¸â€²)â‰¥uiâ€‹(Î¸)âˆ€iâˆˆSâ‡”uiâ€‹(Î¸)uiâ€‹(Î¸â€²)â€‹â‰¥1âˆ€iâˆˆS

with at least one strict inequality.

The problem is, can we directly sum it up, then we have âˆ‘iui(Î¸â€²)ui(Î¸)>n\sum_i\frac{u_i(\theta')}{u_i(\theta)}\gt nâˆ‘iâ€‹uiâ€‹(Î¸)uiâ€‹(Î¸â€²)â€‹>n???

There is a counterexample:

  • n=2n=2n=2, Î¸\thetaÎ¸ is core-stable, we only have two feasible predictors Î¸,Î¸â€²:Î¸â€²â‰ Î¸\theta,\theta':\theta'\neq\thetaÎ¸,Î¸â€²:Î¸â€²î€ =Î¸, Ïµâ†’0+\epsilon\to0^+Ïµâ†’0+.

    agent 111agent 222
    Î¸\thetaÎ¸111111
    Î¸â€²\theta'Î¸â€²2âˆ’Ïµ2-\epsilon2âˆ’Ïµ1âˆ’Ïµ1-\epsilon1âˆ’Ïµ

  • Verifying the core-stability of Î¸\thetaÎ¸:

    • For S={1}S=\{1\}S={1}, we have âˆ£Sâˆ£nui(Î¸â€²)=12u1(Î¸â€²)=1âˆ’Ïµ2<1=u1(Î¸)\frac{|S|}{n}u_i(\theta')=\frac{1}{2}u_1(\theta')=1-\frac{\epsilon}{2}\lt1=u_1(\theta)nâˆ£Sâˆ£â€‹uiâ€‹(Î¸â€²)=21â€‹u1â€‹(Î¸â€²)=1âˆ’2Ïµâ€‹<1=u1â€‹(Î¸). Which satisfy the condition.
    • For S={2}S=\{2\}S={2}, we have 12u2(Î¸â€²)=1âˆ’Ïµ2<1=u2(Î¸)\frac{1}{2}u_2(\theta')=\frac{1-\epsilon}{2}\lt1=u_2(\theta)21â€‹u2â€‹(Î¸â€²)=21âˆ’Ïµâ€‹<1=u2â€‹(Î¸). Which satisfy the condition.
    • For S={1,2}S=\{1,2\}S={1,2}, we have u1(Î¸â€²)=2âˆ’Ïµ>1=u1(Î¸)u_1(\theta')=2-\epsilon\gt1=u_1(\theta)u1â€‹(Î¸â€²)=2âˆ’Ïµ>1=u1â€‹(Î¸) and u2(Î¸â€²)=1âˆ’Ïµ<1=u2(Î¸)u_2(\theta')=1-\epsilon\lt1=u_2(\theta)u2â€‹(Î¸â€²)=1âˆ’Ïµ<1=u2â€‹(Î¸). Which also satisfy the condition that some scaled utility is less than the original utility.

    But âˆ‘iui(Î¸â€²)ui(Î¸)=u1(Î¸â€²)u1(Î¸)+u2(Î¸â€²)u2(Î¸)=3âˆ’2Ïµ>2\sum_i\frac{u_i(\theta')}{u_i(\theta)}=\frac{u_1(\theta')}{u_1(\theta)}+\frac{u_2(\theta')}{u_2(\theta)}=3-2\epsilon\gt2âˆ‘iâ€‹uiâ€‹(Î¸)uiâ€‹(Î¸â€²)â€‹=u1â€‹(Î¸)u1â€‹(Î¸â€²)â€‹+u2â€‹(Î¸)u2â€‹(Î¸â€²)â€‹=3âˆ’2Ïµ>2!

Scaled factor âˆ£Sâˆ£/n|S|/nâˆ£Sâˆ£/n suggests some kind of proportionality here. Basically core-stability means there is no big benefit for agent to form a coalition.

Core means â€œno deviating subgroupâ€

Core stability is very strong, only exists in special cases.

Advantage

More fair than FedAvg. MMM is a very large integer.

Agent 1Agent 2Agent 3
Î¸1\theta_1Î¸1â€‹aaaaaaMâ‹…aM\cdot aMâ‹…a
Î¸2\theta_2Î¸2â€‹10a10a10a10a10a10a0.9Mâ‹…a0.9M\cdot a0.9Mâ‹…a

In FedAvg, Î¸2\theta_2Î¸2â€‹ is preferred, but not fair to Agent 1 and 2. (They have incentive to collide.)

Robustness to poor local data quality of agents.

â—Scaling the utility of any single agents does not change the core-stable allocation.

â—Some Ideas around Sum-of-ratio Property

Is there scenario s.t. none of predictors is core-stable?

Yes. The example

agent 111agent 222
Î¸\thetaÎ¸1112+Ïµ2+\epsilon2+Ïµ
Î¸â€²\theta'Î¸â€²2+Ïµ2+\epsilon2+Ïµ111

shows that none of Î¸,Î¸â€²\theta,\theta'Î¸,Î¸â€² is core-stable.

Some New Definitions

Ideas from Iannis. I was amazed by his ability to invent some new notions ğŸ˜®

ğŸ“–Definition of pessimistic price of core-stability:

PoCSpessimistic=maxâ¡Î¸Â isÂ core-stablemaxâ¡Î¸â€²âˆˆPâˆ‘iâˆˆ[n]ui(Î¸â€²)ui(Î¸)PoCS_{pessimistic}=\max_{\theta\text{ is core-stable}}\max_{\theta'\in P}\sum_{i\in[n]}\frac{u_i(\theta')}{u_i(\theta)}PoCSpessimisticâ€‹=Î¸Â isÂ core-stablemaxâ€‹Î¸â€²âˆˆPmaxâ€‹iâˆˆ[n]âˆ‘â€‹uiâ€‹(Î¸)uiâ€‹(Î¸â€²)â€‹

ğŸ“–Definition of optimistic price of core-stability:

PoCSoptimistic=minâ¡Î¸Â isÂ core-stablemaxâ¡Î¸â€²âˆˆPâˆ‘iâˆˆ[n]ui(Î¸â€²)ui(Î¸)PoCS_{optimistic}=\min_{\theta\text{ is core-stable}}\max_{\theta'\in P}\sum_{i\in[n]}\frac{u_i(\theta')}{u_i(\theta)}PoCSoptimisticâ€‹=Î¸Â isÂ core-stableminâ€‹Î¸â€²âˆˆPmaxâ€‹iâˆˆ[n]âˆ‘â€‹uiâ€‹(Î¸)uiâ€‹(Î¸â€²)â€‹

Conjecture about Price of Core-Stability (Has been disproved)

If the set of core-stable predictors is non-empty, does one predictor in the set be the optimistic price of core-stability?

We want to proof/disproof this conjectures.

Letâ€™s consider the scenario with two agents.

agents\predictorsÎ¸\thetaÎ¸â€¦Î¸â€²â€²\theta''Î¸â€²â€²â€¦
11â€¦?â€¦
21â€¦?â€¦

Assume that Î¸\thetaÎ¸ is core-stable. The question is, does there exist predictor Î¸â€²â€²\theta''Î¸â€²â€² that minimizing maxâ¡Î¸â€²âˆˆPâˆ‘iâˆˆ[n]ui(Î¸â€²)ui(Î¸â€²â€²)\max_{\theta'\in P}\sum_{i\in[n]}\frac{u_i(\theta')}{u_i(\theta'')}maxÎ¸â€²âˆˆPâ€‹âˆ‘iâˆˆ[n]â€‹uiâ€‹(Î¸â€²â€²)uiâ€‹(Î¸â€²)â€‹ and not core-stable? If the answer is true, then we disproof the conjecture.

Disprove it

Consider the scenario with 2 agents and 3 feasible predictors:

agents\predictorsÎ¸1\theta_1Î¸1â€‹Î¸2\theta_2Î¸2â€‹Î¸3\theta_3Î¸3â€‹
11111âˆ’Ïµ1-\epsilon1âˆ’Ïµ222
21112221âˆ’Ïµ1-\epsilon1âˆ’Ïµ

By symmetry, Î¸2\theta_2Î¸2â€‹ and Î¸3\theta_3Î¸3â€‹ are equivalent.

Check whether Î¸1\theta_1Î¸1â€‹ is core-stable

  • Consider S={1}S=\{1\}S={1}:

    12u1(Î¸2)=1âˆ’Ïµ2<1=u1(Î¸1)=112u1(Î¸3)=22=1â‰¤1=u1(Î¸1)=1\frac{1}{2}u_1(\theta_2)=\frac{1-\epsilon}{2}\lt 1=u_1(\theta_1)=1\\\frac{1}{2}u_1(\theta_3)=\frac{2}{2}=1\le 1=u_1(\theta_1)=121â€‹u1â€‹(Î¸2â€‹)=21âˆ’Ïµâ€‹<1=u1â€‹(Î¸1â€‹)=121â€‹u1â€‹(Î¸3â€‹)=22â€‹=1â‰¤1=u1â€‹(Î¸1â€‹)=1

  • Consider S={2}S=\{2\}S={2}:

    12u2(Î¸3)=1âˆ’Ïµ2<1=u2(Î¸1)=112u2(Î¸2)=22=1â‰¤1=u2(Î¸1)=1\frac{1}{2}u_2(\theta_3)=\frac{1-\epsilon}{2}\lt 1=u_2(\theta_1)=1\\\frac{1}{2}u_2(\theta_2)=\frac{2}{2}=1\le 1=u_2(\theta_1)=121â€‹u2â€‹(Î¸3â€‹)=21âˆ’Ïµâ€‹<1=u2â€‹(Î¸1â€‹)=121â€‹u2â€‹(Î¸2â€‹)=22â€‹=1â‰¤1=u2â€‹(Î¸1â€‹)=1

  • Consider S={1,2}S=\{1,2\}S={1,2}:

    22u1(Î¸2)=1âˆ’Ïµ<u1(Î¸1)=1,22u2(Î¸2)=2>u2(Î¸1)=122u1(Î¸3)=2>u1(Î¸1)=1,22u1(Î¸3)=1âˆ’Ïµ<u1(Î¸1)=1\frac{2}{2}u_1(\theta_2)=1-\epsilon\lt u_1(\theta_1)=1,\frac{2}{2}u_2(\theta_2)=2\gt u_2(\theta_1)=1\\\frac{2}{2}u_1(\theta_3)=2\gt u_1(\theta_1)=1,\frac{2}{2}u_1(\theta_3)=1-\epsilon\lt u_1(\theta_1)=122â€‹u1â€‹(Î¸2â€‹)=1âˆ’Ïµ<u1â€‹(Î¸1â€‹)=1,22â€‹u2â€‹(Î¸2â€‹)=2>u2â€‹(Î¸1â€‹)=122â€‹u1â€‹(Î¸3â€‹)=2>u1â€‹(Î¸1â€‹)=1,22â€‹u1â€‹(Î¸3â€‹)=1âˆ’Ïµ<u1â€‹(Î¸1â€‹)=1

There is no subset satisfying all scaled value is greater or equal to original value. Thus, Î¸1\theta_1Î¸1â€‹ is core-stable.

Check whether Î¸2,Î¸3\theta_2,\theta_3Î¸2â€‹,Î¸3â€‹ are core-stable

It suffices to check only Î¸2\theta_2Î¸2â€‹.

  • Consider S={1}S=\{1\}S={1}:

    12u1(Î¸1)=12<u1(Î¸2)=1âˆ’Ïµ12u1(Î¸3)=1>u1(Î¸2)=1âˆ’Ïµ\frac{1}{2}u_1(\theta_1)=\frac{1}{2}\lt u_1(\theta_2)=1-\epsilon\\\frac{1}{2}u_1(\theta_3)=1\gt u_1(\theta_2)=1-\epsilon21â€‹u1â€‹(Î¸1â€‹)=21â€‹<u1â€‹(Î¸2â€‹)=1âˆ’Ïµ21â€‹u1â€‹(Î¸3â€‹)=1>u1â€‹(Î¸2â€‹)=1âˆ’Ïµ

    Here scaled utility of Î¸3\theta_3Î¸3â€‹ is strictly better than that of Î¸2\theta_2Î¸2â€‹.

Thus Î¸2,Î¸3\theta_2,\theta_3Î¸2â€‹,Î¸3â€‹ are not core-stable.

Check the Sum of Ratio

For Î¸1\theta_1Î¸1â€‹:

âˆ‘iâˆˆ{1,2}ui(Î¸2)ui(Î¸1)=3âˆ’Ïµâˆ‘iâˆˆ{1,2}ui(Î¸3)ui(Î¸1)=3âˆ’Ïµâˆ´maxâ¡Î¸â€²â‰ Î¸1âˆ‘iâˆˆ{1,2}ui(Î¸â€²)ui(Î¸1)â‰ˆ3\sum_{i\in\{1,2\}}\frac{u_i(\theta_2)}{u_i(\theta_1)}=3-\epsilon\\\sum_{i\in\{1,2\}}\frac{u_i(\theta_3)}{u_i(\theta_1)}=3-\epsilon\\\therefore\max_{\theta'\neq\theta_1}\sum_{i\in\{1,2\}}\frac{u_i(\theta')}{u_i(\theta_1)}\approx3iâˆˆ{1,2}âˆ‘â€‹uiâ€‹(Î¸1â€‹)uiâ€‹(Î¸2â€‹)â€‹=3âˆ’Ïµiâˆˆ{1,2}âˆ‘â€‹uiâ€‹(Î¸1â€‹)uiâ€‹(Î¸3â€‹)â€‹=3âˆ’Ïµâˆ´Î¸â€²î€ =Î¸1â€‹maxâ€‹iâˆˆ{1,2}âˆ‘â€‹uiâ€‹(Î¸1â€‹)uiâ€‹(Î¸â€²)â€‹â‰ˆ3

For Î¸2\theta_2Î¸2â€‹:

âˆ‘iâˆˆ{1,2}ui(Î¸1)ui(Î¸2)=12+11âˆ’Ïµâ‰ˆ32âˆ‘iâˆˆ{1,2}ui(Î¸3)ui(Î¸2)=21âˆ’Ïµ+1âˆ’Ïµ2â‰ˆ52âˆ´maxâ¡Î¸â€²â‰ Î¸2âˆ‘iâˆˆ{1,2}ui(Î¸â€²)ui(Î¸2)â‰ˆ52\sum_{i\in\{1,2\}}\frac{u_i(\theta_1)}{u_i(\theta_2)}=\frac{1}{2}+\frac{1}{1-\epsilon}\approx\frac{3}{2}\\\sum_{i\in\{1,2\}}\frac{u_i(\theta_3)}{u_i(\theta_2)}=\frac{2}{1-\epsilon}+\frac{1-\epsilon}{2}\approx\frac{5}{2}\\\therefore\max_{\theta'\neq\theta_2}\sum_{i\in\{1,2\}}\frac{u_i(\theta')}{u_i(\theta_2)}\approx\frac{5}{2}iâˆˆ{1,2}âˆ‘â€‹uiâ€‹(Î¸2â€‹)uiâ€‹(Î¸1â€‹)â€‹=21â€‹+1âˆ’Ïµ1â€‹â‰ˆ23â€‹iâˆˆ{1,2}âˆ‘â€‹uiâ€‹(Î¸2â€‹)uiâ€‹(Î¸3â€‹)â€‹=1âˆ’Ïµ2â€‹+21âˆ’Ïµâ€‹â‰ˆ25â€‹âˆ´Î¸â€²î€ =Î¸2â€‹maxâ€‹iâˆˆ{1,2}âˆ‘â€‹uiâ€‹(Î¸2â€‹)uiâ€‹(Î¸â€²)â€‹â‰ˆ25â€‹

By symmetry, maxâ¡Î¸â€²â‰ Î¸3âˆ‘iâˆˆ{1,2}ui(Î¸â€²)ui(Î¸3)â‰ˆ52\max_{\theta'\neq\theta_3}\sum_{i\in\{1,2\}}\frac{u_i(\theta')}{u_i(\theta_3)}\approx\frac{5}{2}maxÎ¸â€²î€ =Î¸3â€‹â€‹âˆ‘iâˆˆ{1,2}â€‹uiâ€‹(Î¸3â€‹)uiâ€‹(Î¸â€²)â€‹â‰ˆ25â€‹.

The max of sum is not minimized by the only core-stable predictor.

Core-Stability in FL

CoreFed exists in Linear Regression and Logistic Regression (Classification)

Approximate core stable predictor exists in Deep Neural Network.

Existence

ğŸ¤”Core-Stability exist in FL if:

  1. Utility function is continuous.

  2. The conical combination of utility functions is convex.

    âˆ€âŸ¨Î±1,â‹¯â€‰,Î±nâŸ©âˆˆRâ‰¥0n\forall\langle\alpha_1,\cdots,\alpha_n\rangle\in\mathbb R_{\ge0}^nâˆ€âŸ¨Î±1â€‹,â‹¯,Î±nâ€‹âŸ©âˆˆRâ‰¥0nâ€‹, the set C={Î¸âˆ£âˆ‘iâˆˆ[n]Î±iui(Î¸)}C=\{\theta|\sum_{i\in[n]}\alpha_iu_i(\theta)\}C={Î¸âˆ£âˆ‘iâˆˆ[n]â€‹Î±iâ€‹uiâ€‹(Î¸)} is convex.

ğŸ¤”Important theorem: Kakutaniâ€™s Fixed Point Theorem: A set valued function Ï•:Dâ†’2D\phi:D\to2^DÏ•:Dâ†’2D admits a fixed point, i.e. âˆƒdâˆˆD\exist d\in DâˆƒdâˆˆD, s.t. dâˆˆÏ•(d)d\in\phi(d)dâˆˆÏ•(d), if

  1. DDD is non-empty, compact, and convex

Compact: The set is closed (It must contains all its boundary points), and bounded (It can be covered by a â€œsphereâ€ with certain radius)

Convex: A set is convex if, for any two points xxx and yyy in the set, the line segment connecting xxx and yyy also lies entirely within the set. Mathematically, for any x,yâˆˆSx,y\in Sx,yâˆˆS and any tâˆˆ[0,1]t \in [0, 1]tâˆˆ[0,1], the point: tx+(1âˆ’t)yâˆˆStx+(1âˆ’t)y\in Stx+(1âˆ’t)yâˆˆS.

  1. âˆ€dâˆˆD,Ï•(d)\forall d\in D,\phi(d)âˆ€dâˆˆD,Ï•(d) is non-empty, compact, and convex.
  2. Ï•(â‹…)\phi(\cdot)Ï•(â‹…) has a closed graph. i.e., âˆ€\forallâˆ€ sequence (di)iâˆˆN(d_i)_{i\in\mathbb N}(diâ€‹)iâˆˆNâ€‹ converging to dâˆ—d^*dâˆ— and (ei)iâˆˆN(e_i)_{i\in\mathbb N}(eiâ€‹)iâˆˆNâ€‹ converging to eâˆ—e^*eâˆ—, s.t. diâˆˆDd_i\in Ddiâ€‹âˆˆD and eiâˆˆÏ•(di)e_i\in\phi(d_i)eiâ€‹âˆˆÏ•(diâ€‹), we have eâˆ—âˆˆÏ•(dâˆ—)e^*\in\phi(d^*)eâˆ—âˆˆÏ•(dâˆ—).

Define Core-Stable Feasible Predictors

âˆ€Î¸âˆˆP\forall\theta\in Pâˆ€Î¸âˆˆP, Ï•(Î¸)={argâ¡maxâ¡dâˆˆPâˆ‘iâˆˆ[n]ui(d)ui(Î¸)}\phi(\theta)=\{\arg\max_{d\in P}\sum_{i\in[n]}\frac{u_i(d)}{u_i(\theta)}\}Ï•(Î¸)={argmaxdâˆˆPâ€‹âˆ‘iâˆˆ[n]â€‹uiâ€‹(Î¸)uiâ€‹(d)â€‹}.

Lemma 4.1: Let Î¸âˆˆP\theta\in PÎ¸âˆˆP be s.t. Î¸âˆˆÏ•(Î¸)\theta\in\phi(\theta)Î¸âˆˆÏ•(Î¸) (It is a fixed point). Then Î¸\thetaÎ¸ is a core-stable predictor.

Proof by contradiction.

By Takutaniâ€™s Theorem, it suffices to show that Ï•(â‹…)\phi(\cdot)Ï•(â‹…) has a closed graph, to ensure that it admits a fixed point.

Lemma 4.2: Ï•(â‹…)\phi(\cdot)Ï•(â‹…) has a closed graph.

Hard proof.

ğŸ¤”Theorem 1. In FL, where utilities are continuous and any conical combination of utilities is convex, a core-stable predictor exists.

âš ï¸If we change dâˆˆPd\in PdâˆˆP to dâˆˆB(Î¸,r)d\in\mathcal B(\theta, r)dâˆˆB(Î¸,r), if the two condition still holds within a radius of rrr of every point. The conditions tend to be true in DNN of small rrr. Then the predictor is locally core-stable.

Computation of Core-Stable Predictor

There is efficient way to compute core-stable predictor.

It is optima of convex program:

maximizeÂ L(Î¸)=âˆ‘iâˆˆ[n]logâ¡(ui(Î¸))Â orÂ âˆiâˆˆ[n]ui(Î¸)subjectÂ toÂ Î¸âˆˆP\text{maximize }\mathcal L(\theta)=\sum_{i\in[n]}\log(u_i(\theta))\text{ or }\prod_{i\in[n]}u_i(\theta)\\\text{subject to }\theta\in PmaximizeÂ L(Î¸)=iâˆˆ[n]âˆ‘â€‹log(uiâ€‹(Î¸))Â orÂ iâˆˆ[n]âˆâ€‹uiâ€‹(Î¸)subjectÂ toÂ Î¸âˆˆP

The object reminds me of Nash Social WelfareğŸ˜

Utility of each agent is concave, thus above program is convex. Thus this program is concave maximization subject to convex constraint.

ğŸ¤”Theorem 2. If uiu_iuiâ€‹ is concave for all iii, then any predictor Î¸âˆ—\theta^*Î¸âˆ— maximizes the convex program is core stable.

Proof by contradiction

âˆ‘iâˆˆ[n]ui(Î¸â€²)ui(Î¸âˆ—)â‰¤n.\sum_{i\in[n]}\frac{u_i(\theta')}{u_i(\theta^*)}\le n.iâˆˆ[n]âˆ‘â€‹uiâ€‹(Î¸âˆ—)uiâ€‹(Î¸â€²)â€‹â‰¤n.

If Î¸âˆ—\theta^*Î¸âˆ— is not core-stable, there must exist Î¸â€²\theta'Î¸â€² and subset SSS, s.t.

ui(Î¸â€²)â‰¥nâˆ£Sâˆ£ui(Î¸âˆ—)u_i(\theta')\ge\frac{n}{|S|}u_i(\theta^*)uiâ€‹(Î¸â€²)â‰¥âˆ£Sâˆ£nâ€‹uiâ€‹(Î¸âˆ—)

for all iii with at least one strict inequality.

Thus for any Î¸â‰ Î¸â€²\theta\neq\theta'Î¸î€ =Î¸â€²,

âˆ‘iâˆˆ[n]ui(Î¸)ui(Î¸â€²)â‰¥âˆ‘iâˆˆSui(Î¸)ui(Î¸â€²)>n/âˆ£Sâˆ£â‹…âˆ£Sâˆ£=n,\sum_{i\in[n]}\frac{u_i(\theta)}{u_i(\theta')}\ge\sum_{i\in S}\frac{u_i(\theta)}{u_i(\theta')}\gt n/|S|\cdot|S|=n,iâˆˆ[n]âˆ‘â€‹uiâ€‹(Î¸â€²)uiâ€‹(Î¸)â€‹â‰¥iâˆˆSâˆ‘â€‹uiâ€‹(Î¸â€²)uiâ€‹(Î¸)â€‹>n/âˆ£Sâˆ£â‹…âˆ£Sâˆ£=n,

admitting contradiction.

Î¸âˆ—\theta^*Î¸âˆ— must be Pareto Optimal.

CoreFed

Stochastic Gradient Descent.

nnn finite samples {(xi,yi)}iâˆˆ[n]\{(x_i,y_i)\}_{i\in[n]}{(xiâ€‹,yiâ€‹)}iâˆˆ[n]â€‹ drawn from data distribution P\mathcal PP, which constitute empirical distribution P^n\hat{\mathcal P}_nP^nâ€‹. The gradient can be expressed as an conical combination of the gradients of each group:

âˆ‡Î¸(Î¸)=âˆ‘iâˆˆ[n]âˆ‡Î¸ui(Î¸)ui(Î¸)=âˆ‘iâˆˆ[n]âˆ’âˆ‡Î¸E(x,y)âˆ¼P^n(i)â„“(fÎ¸(x),y)Miâˆ’E(x,y)âˆ¼P^n(i)â„“(fÎ¸(x),y)\nabla_\theta\mathcal(\theta)=\sum_{i\in[n]}\frac{\nabla_\theta u_i(\theta)}{u_i(\theta)}=\sum_{i\in[n]}\frac{-\nabla_\theta\mathbb E_{(x,y)\sim\hat{\mathcal P}_n^{(i)}}\ell(f_\theta(x),y)}{M_i-\mathbb E_{(x,y)\sim\hat{\mathcal P}_n^{(i)}}\ell(f_\theta(x),y)}âˆ‡Î¸â€‹(Î¸)=iâˆˆ[n]âˆ‘â€‹uiâ€‹(Î¸)âˆ‡Î¸â€‹uiâ€‹(Î¸)â€‹=iâˆˆ[n]âˆ‘â€‹Miâ€‹âˆ’E(x,y)âˆ¼P^n(i)â€‹â€‹â„“(fÎ¸â€‹(x),y)âˆ’âˆ‡Î¸â€‹E(x,y)âˆ¼P^n(i)â€‹â€‹â„“(fÎ¸â€‹(x),y)â€‹

For each group, reweight its gradients by (Miâˆ’E(x,y)âˆ¼P^n(i)â„“(fÎ¸(x),y))âˆ’1(M_i-\mathbb E_{(x,y)\sim\hat{\mathcal P}_n^{(i)}}\ell(f_\theta(x),y))^{-1}(Miâ€‹âˆ’E(x,y)âˆ¼P^n(i)â€‹â€‹â„“(fÎ¸â€‹(x),y))âˆ’1 and then sum up to get the final weight update. This is base protocol.

In CoreFed the model weights are directly averaged and aggregated at each iteration.

Pseudo Code of CoreFed

Input: Number of clients KKK, number of rounds TTT, epochs EEE, learning rate Î·\etaÎ·.

Output: Model weights Î¸âŠ¤\theta^\topÎ¸âŠ¤

  1. For tâ†0t\gets0tâ†0 to Tâˆ’1T-1Tâˆ’1 do

    • Server selects a subset of KKK devices StS_tStâ€‹

    • Server sends weights Î¸t\theta^tÎ¸t to all selected devices

    • Each select device sâˆˆSts\in S_tsâˆˆStâ€‹ updates Î¸t\theta^tÎ¸t for EEE epochs of SGD with learning rate Î·\etaÎ· to obtain new weights Î¸Ë‰st\bar\theta_s^tÎ¸Ë‰stâ€‹

    • Each select devices sâˆˆSts\in S_tsâˆˆStâ€‹ computes

      Î”Î¸st=Î¸Ë‰stâˆ’Î¸t,Lst=1âˆ£Dsâˆ£âˆ‘i=1âˆ£Dsâˆ£â„“(fÎ¸t(xs(i)),ys(i))\Delta\theta_s^t=\bar\theta_s^t-\theta^t,\\\mathcal L_s^t=\frac{1}{|\mathcal D_s|}\sum_{i=1}^{|\mathcal D_s|}\ell(f_{\theta^t}(x_s^{(i)}),y_s^{(i)})Î”Î¸stâ€‹=Î¸Ë‰stâ€‹âˆ’Î¸t,Lstâ€‹=âˆ£Dsâ€‹âˆ£1â€‹i=1âˆ‘âˆ£Dsâ€‹âˆ£â€‹â„“(fÎ¸tâ€‹(xs(i)â€‹),ys(i)â€‹)

      where Ds={(xs(i),ys(i)):iâˆˆ[âˆ£Dsâˆ£]}\mathcal D_s=\{(x_s^{(i)},y_s^{(i)}):i\in[|\mathcal D_s|]\}Dsâ€‹={(xs(i)â€‹,ys(i)â€‹):iâˆˆ[âˆ£Dsâ€‹âˆ£]} is the training dataset on device sss

    • Each selected device sâˆˆSts\in S_tsâˆˆStâ€‹ sends Î”Î¸s\Delta \theta_sÎ”Î¸sâ€‹ and Ls\mathcal L_sLsâ€‹ back to the server

    • Server updates Î¸t+1\theta^{t+1}Î¸t+1 following

      Î¸t+1â†Î¸t+1âˆ£Stâˆ£âˆ‘sâˆˆStÎ”Î¸stMsâˆ’Lst.\theta^{t+1}\gets\theta^t+\frac{1}{|S_t|}\sum_{s\in S_t}\frac{\Delta\theta_s^t}{M_s-\mathcal L_s^t}.Î¸t+1â†Î¸t+âˆ£Stâ€‹âˆ£1â€‹sâˆˆStâ€‹âˆ‘â€‹Msâ€‹âˆ’Lstâ€‹Î”Î¸stâ€‹â€‹.

end

Core-Stability in Linear Regression and Classification with Logistic Regression

Utility function is concave.

uiu_iuiâ€‹ is concave â‡”â„“\Lrarr \ellâ‡”â„“ is convex

nnn finite samples {(xi,yi)}iâˆˆ[n]\{(x_i,y_i)\}_{i\in[n]}{(xiâ€‹,yiâ€‹)}iâˆˆ[n]â€‹ drawn from data distribution P\mathcal PP, which constitute empirical distribution P^n\hat{\mathcal P}_nP^nâ€‹.

Linear Regression

fÎ¸(x)=Î¸âŠ¤xf_\theta(x)=\theta^\top xfÎ¸â€‹(x)=Î¸âŠ¤x.

Regression loss E(x,y)âˆ¼P^n(i)â„“(fÎ¸(x),y)=E(x,y)âˆ¼P^n(i)(Î¸âŠ¤xâˆ’y)2\mathbb E_{(x,y)\sim\hat{\mathcal P}_n^{(i)}}\ell(f_\theta(x),y)=\mathbb E_{(x,y)\sim\hat{\mathcal P}_n^{(i)}}(\theta^\top x-y)^2E(x,y)âˆ¼P^n(i)â€‹â€‹â„“(fÎ¸â€‹(x),y)=E(x,y)âˆ¼P^n(i)â€‹â€‹(Î¸âŠ¤xâˆ’y)2 would be convex in Î¸\thetaÎ¸

ğŸ¤”Lemma: CoreFed determines a core-stable predictor in a federated learning setting training linear regression

Classification with Logistic Regression

Given a classifier Î¸\thetaÎ¸ and a scalar câˆˆRc\in RcâˆˆR, and agents iiiâ€™s loss is â„“i(Î¸,c)=âˆ£âˆ£Î¸âˆ£âˆ£22+Î±â‹…âˆ‘iâˆˆ[n]logâ¡(expâ¡(âˆ’yi(Î¸âŠ¤xi+c))+1)\ell_i(\theta,c)=\frac{||\theta||_2}{2}+\alpha\cdot\sum_{i\in[n]}\log(\exp(-y_i(\theta^\top x_i+c))+1)â„“iâ€‹(Î¸,c)=2âˆ£âˆ£Î¸âˆ£âˆ£2â€‹â€‹+Î±â‹…âˆ‘iâˆˆ[n]â€‹log(exp(âˆ’yiâ€‹(Î¸âŠ¤xiâ€‹+c))+1). â„“i\ell_iâ„“iâ€‹ is convex.

Thus, ui(Î¸,c)=Miâˆ’â„“i(Î¸,c)u_i(\theta,c)=M_i-\ell_i(\theta,c)uiâ€‹(Î¸,c)=Miâ€‹âˆ’â„“iâ€‹(Î¸,c) where Mi=argâ¡maxâ¡Î¸âˆˆP,câˆˆR(â„“i(Î¸,c))M_i=\arg\max_{\theta\in P,c\in\mathbb R}(\ell_i(\theta,c))Miâ€‹=argmaxÎ¸âˆˆP,câˆˆRâ€‹(â„“iâ€‹(Î¸,c)) is concave.

ğŸ¤”Lemma: CoreFed determines a core-stable predictor in a federated learning setting training classification with logistic regression.

entry.title: Efficient ReliK 2 Possible Parallelization Idea
entry.content:
Some ideas from Maximilian.

Recap Pseudo Code

Look at the Pseudo code again:

Input: KG K:âŸ¨E,R,FâŸ©\mathcal K:\langle\mathcal E,\mathcal R,\mathcal F\rangleK:âŸ¨E,R,FâŸ©, triple xhrt=(h,r,t)âˆˆFx_{hrt}=(h,r,t)\in\mathcal Fxhrtâ€‹=(h,r,t)âˆˆF, embedding score function s:EÃ—RÃ—Eâ†’Rs:\mathcal E\times\mathcal R\times\mathcal E\to\mathbb Rs:EÃ—RÃ—Eâ†’R, sample size kâˆˆNk\in\mathbb NkâˆˆN

Output: ReliKLB(xhrt)ReliK_{LB}(x_{hrt})ReliKLBâ€‹(xhrtâ€‹) or ReliKApx(xhrt)ReliK_{Apx}(x_{hrt})ReliKApxâ€‹(xhrtâ€‹)

  1. SHâ†S_H\getsSHâ€‹â† sample kkk triples from Nâˆ’(h)\mathcal N^-(h)Nâˆ’(h); STâ†S_T\getsSTâ€‹â† sample kkk triples from Nâˆ’(t)N^-(t)Nâˆ’(t).

  2. rankHâ†1rank_H\gets1rankHâ€‹â†1; rankTâ†1rank_T\gets1rankTâ€‹â†1

  3. for xhâ€²râ€²tâ€²âˆˆSHâˆªSTx_{h'r't'}\in S_H\cup S_Txhâ€²râ€²tâ€²â€‹âˆˆSHâ€‹âˆªSTâ€‹ do

    • If s(xhrt)â‰¤s(xhâ€²râ€²tâ€²)s(x_{hrt})\le s(x_{h'r't'})s(xhrtâ€‹)â‰¤s(xhâ€²râ€²tâ€²â€‹) then

      • if hâ€²=hh'=hhâ€²=h then

        rankHâ†rankH+1rank_H\gets rank_H+1rankHâ€‹â†rankHâ€‹+1

      • if tâ€²=tt'=ttâ€²=t then

        rankTâ†rankT+1rank_T\gets rank_T+1rankTâ€‹â†rankTâ€‹+1

  4. return 12(1rankH+âˆ£Nâˆ’(h)âˆ£âˆ’âˆ£SHâˆ£+1rankT+âˆ£Nâˆ’(t)âˆ£âˆ’âˆ£STâˆ£)\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{1}{rank_H+|\mathcal N^-(h)|-|S_H|}+\frac{1}{rank_T+|\mathcal N^-(t)|-|S_T|}\right)21â€‹(rankHâ€‹+âˆ£Nâˆ’(h)âˆ£âˆ’âˆ£SHâ€‹âˆ£1â€‹+rankTâ€‹+âˆ£Nâˆ’(t)âˆ£âˆ’âˆ£STâ€‹âˆ£1â€‹) for ReliKLBReliK_{LB}ReliKLBâ€‹

    or 12(1rankHNâˆ’(h)âˆ£SHâˆ£+1rankTNâˆ’(t)âˆ£STâˆ£)\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{1}{rank_H\frac{\mathcal N^-(h)}{|S_H|}}+\frac{1}{rank_T\frac{\mathcal N^-(t)}{|S_T|}}\right)21â€‹(rankHâ€‹âˆ£SHâ€‹âˆ£Nâˆ’(h)â€‹1â€‹+rankTâ€‹âˆ£STâ€‹âˆ£Nâˆ’(t)â€‹1â€‹) for ReliKApxReliK_{Apx}ReliKApxâ€‹

Ideas for Parallelization

Idea 1 Parallel Sampling

Sampling the negative sets SHS_HSHâ€‹ and STS_TSTâ€‹ can be done in parallel for both head and tail entities. GPU-based libraries like PyTorch can handle large-scale sampling efficiently on GPUs.

I will think about it.

Idea 2 Rank Update

For each sampled triple xhâ€²râ€²tâ€²x_{h'r't'}xhâ€²râ€²tâ€²â€‹, it can be parallelized across all samples in SHâˆªSTS_H\cup S_TSHâ€‹âˆªSTâ€‹. For-parallel

GPUs are very efficient at handling this kind of parallel computation, especially with batched matrix operations.

âœ…I will be working on this.

Will there be some write-after-write or read-after-write issues? Should I add some write-lock?

entry.title: Efficient ReliK 1 Paper Reading
entry.content:
This is one of the two projects I undertake in 24 Fall semester, which is related to data mining.

Supervisor: Assoc. Prof. Davide Mottin, PhD Student Maximilian Egger.

Generally speaking, they have already developed a new method, ReliK, for measuring knowledge graph embeddings, but they want to speed it up with GPUs.

So my project is focusing on this. I wish to speed them up with some tolerance on small accuracy loss.

I need to first get familiar with the paper, ReliK: A Reliability Measure for Knowledge Graph Embedding. Here is some digest and notes from it.

Abstract

Object of ReliK: To assess a priori how well a knowledge graph embedding (KGE) will perform on a downstream task and in a specific part of the knowledge graph.

ReliK aka Reliability measure of KGEs.

  • It relies only on KGE embedding scores.
  • Task independent
  • KGE independent

Correlates well with some downstream tasks:

  • tail/relation prediction, triple classification
  • rule mining, question answering.

Introduction

KGE: generate a vector representation for entities and relationships of a KG.

Motivation: KEG method depends on which downstream task. We want to unified, global measure to quantify the reliability of KGE method.

Contributions: ReliK, principled measure that quantifies the reliability of how a KEG will perform will on a certain downstream task in a specific part of the KG without executing that task or training KG!!!

ReliK is based on the relative ranking of existing KG triples w.r.t. non-existing one.

Preliminaries

Knowledge Graph

KG K:âŸ¨E,R,FâŸ©\mathcal K:\langle\mathcal E,\mathcal R,\mathcal F\rangleK:âŸ¨E,R,FâŸ© is a triple consisting of a set E\mathcal EE of nnn entities, a set R\mathcal RR of relationships, and a set FâŠ‚EÃ—RÃ—E\mathcal F\subset\mathcal E\times\mathcal R\times\mathcal EFâŠ‚EÃ—RÃ—E of mmm facts.

A fact is a triple xhrt=(h,r,t)x_{hrt}=(h,r,t)xhrtâ€‹=(h,r,t). head, relation, tail.

We say xhrtx_{hrt}xhrtâ€‹ is positive if it actually exists in the KG xhrtâˆˆFx_{hrt}\in\mathcal Fxhrtâ€‹âˆˆF, negative otherwise xhrtâˆˆÌ¸Fx_{hrt}\not\in\mathcal Fxhrtâ€‹î€ âˆˆF.

Knowledge Graph Embedding

It is a representation of entities and relationships in a ddd-dimensional space, dâ‰ªâˆ£Eâˆ£d\ll\vert\mathcal E\vertdâ‰ªâˆ£Eâˆ£. The Rd\mathbb R^dRd or Cd\mathbb C^dCd space.

The embedding score: function s:EÃ—RÃ—Eâ†’Rs:\mathcal E\times\mathcal R\times\mathcal E\to\mathbb Rs:EÃ—RÃ—Eâ†’R, which quantifies how like a triple xhrtx_{hrt}xhrtâ€‹ exists in K\mathcal KK based on the embedding of its head, relationship, and tail.

  • Intuitively, the higher s(xhrt)s(x_{hrt})s(xhrtâ€‹), the more likely the existence of xhrtx_{hrt}xhrtâ€‹ in K\mathcal KK.

Key Reliability

Desideratum

  1. Embedding-agnostic. It is independent of the specific KGE method.
  2. Learning-free. No further KGE training.
  3. Task-agnostic. It is independent of downstream task.
  4. Locality. A good predictor of KGE performance locally to a given triple.

ReliK Measure

To fulfill 1. 2.: Treat embedding score as a black-box function that provides only an indication of the actual existence of a triple.

Use position of a triple via a ranking based on embedding score: Assume the relative ranking of a positive triple to be higher than that of negative.

For 4. locality, we assume that a local approach that consider triples relative to a neighborhood is more appropriate.

Definition

For a triple xhrt=(h,r,t)x_{hrt}=(h,r,t)xhrtâ€‹=(h,r,t) we compute the neighbor set Nâˆ’(h)\mathcal N^-(h)Nâˆ’(h) of all possible negative triples, that is triples with head hhh that do not exist in K\mathcal KK.

Similarly, we define Nâˆ’(t)\mathcal N^-(t)Nâˆ’(t) for tail.

Head rank: rankH(xhrt)=âˆ£{xâˆˆNâˆ’(h):s(x)>s(xhrt)}âˆ£+1rank_H(x_{hrt})=|\{x\in\mathcal N^-(h):s(x)\gt s(x_{hrt})\}|+1rankHâ€‹(xhrtâ€‹)=âˆ£{xâˆˆNâˆ’(h):s(x)>s(xhrtâ€‹)}âˆ£+1

Similarly, we define rankT(xhrt)rank_T(x_{hrt})rankTâ€‹(xhrtâ€‹) for tail.

ReliK(xhrt)=12(1rankH(xhrt)+1rankT(xhrt)).ReliK(x_{hrt})=\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{1}{rank_H(x_{hrt})}+\frac{1}{rank_T(x_{hrt})}\right).ReliK(xhrtâ€‹)=21â€‹(rankHâ€‹(xhrtâ€‹)1â€‹+rankTâ€‹(xhrtâ€‹)1â€‹).

ReliK can easily be extended from single triples to sub-graphs by computing the average reliability among the triples in the subgraph.

We define the ReliK score of a set SâŠ†FS\subseteq\mathcal FSâŠ†F of triples as

ReliK(S)=1Sâˆ‘xhrtâˆˆSReliK(xhrt).ReliK(S)=\frac{1}{S}\sum_{x_{hrt}\in S}ReliK(x_{hrt}).ReliK(S)=S1â€‹xhrtâ€‹âˆˆSâˆ‘â€‹ReliK(xhrtâ€‹).

ReliKâˆˆ(0,1]ReliK\in(0,1]ReliKâˆˆ(0,1]. The higher the ReliKReliKReliK, the better reliability.

The lower the head-rank and tail-rank, the better the ranking of xhrtx_{hrt}xhrtâ€‹ induced by the underlying embedding scores.

Efficiently Computing ReliK

Computing original ReliK requires Î©(âˆ£Câˆ£â‹…âˆ£Râˆ£)\Omega(|\mathcal C|\cdot|\mathcal R|)Î©(âˆ£Câˆ£â‹…âˆ£Râˆ£), as it needs to scan the entire negative neighborhood of the target triple.

Computationally TOO HEAVY!!!

We thus propose approximate version of ReliK with efficiency.

Main intuition of approximation is that the precise ranking of many potential triples is not needed.

What it matters is just the number of those triples that exhibit a higher embedding score than the target triple.

Lower bound:

  • ReliKLBReliK_{LB}ReliKLBâ€‹, a lower bound to ReliKReliKReliK by counting the negative triples in the sample that have a lower embedding score.

Approximate

  • ReliKApxReliK_{Apx}ReliKApxâ€‹, estimation of ReliKReliKReliK by evaluating the fraction of triples in the sample that have a higher score than the triple under consideration and scaling this fraction to the total number of negative triples.

Let SHS_HSHâ€‹ be a random subset of kkk elements selected without replacement independently and uniformly at random from negative neighborhood Nâˆ’(h)\mathcal N^-(h)Nâˆ’(h) of the head hhh of a triple xhrtx_{hrt}xhrtâ€‹.

rankHS(xhrt)=âˆ£{xâˆˆSH:s(x)>s(xhrt)}âˆ£+1,rank_H^S(x_{hrt})=\vert\{x\in S_H:s(x)\gt s(x_{hrt})\}\vert+1,rankHSâ€‹(xhrtâ€‹)=âˆ£{xâˆˆSHâ€‹:s(x)>s(xhrtâ€‹)}âˆ£+1,

to be the rank of the score s(xhrt)s(x_{hrt})s(xhrtâ€‹) the KGE assigns to xhrtx_{hrt}xhrtâ€‹, among all the triples in the sample.

Similarly, we compute rankTSrank_T^SrankTSâ€‹ for tailâ€™s neighborhood Nâˆ’(t)\mathcal N^-(t)Nâˆ’(t).

Lower Bound Estimator

rankH(xhrt)â‰¤rankHS(xhrt)+âˆ£Nâˆ’(h)âˆ£âˆ’âˆ£SHâˆ£rankT(xhrt)â‰¤rankTS(xhrt)+âˆ£Nâˆ’(h)âˆ£âˆ’âˆ£STâˆ£â‡’ReliKLB(xhrt)=12(1rankHS(xhrt)+âˆ£Nâˆ’(h)âˆ£âˆ’âˆ£SHâˆ£+1rankTS(xhrt)+âˆ£Nâˆ’(t)âˆ£âˆ’âˆ£STâˆ£),rank_H(x_{hrt})\le rank_H^S(x_{hrt})+|\mathcal N^-(h)|-|S_H|\\rank_T(x_{hrt})\le rank_T^S(x_{hrt})+|\mathcal N^-(h)|-|S_T|\\\Rarr ReliK_{LB}(x_{hrt})=\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{1}{rank_H^S(x_{hrt})+|\mathcal N^-(h)|-|S_H|}+\frac{1}{rank_T^S(x_{hrt})+|\mathcal N^-(t)|-|S_T|}\right),rankHâ€‹(xhrtâ€‹)â‰¤rankHSâ€‹(xhrtâ€‹)+âˆ£Nâˆ’(h)âˆ£âˆ’âˆ£SHâ€‹âˆ£rankTâ€‹(xhrtâ€‹)â‰¤rankTSâ€‹(xhrtâ€‹)+âˆ£Nâˆ’(h)âˆ£âˆ’âˆ£STâ€‹âˆ£â‡’ReliKLBâ€‹(xhrtâ€‹)=21â€‹(rankHSâ€‹(xhrtâ€‹)+âˆ£Nâˆ’(h)âˆ£âˆ’âˆ£SHâ€‹âˆ£1â€‹+rankTSâ€‹(xhrtâ€‹)+âˆ£Nâˆ’(t)âˆ£âˆ’âˆ£STâ€‹âˆ£1â€‹),

It holds that ReliKLB(xhrt)â‰¤ReliK(xhrt)ReliK_{LB}(x_{hrt})\le ReliK(x_{hrt})ReliKLBâ€‹(xhrtâ€‹)â‰¤ReliK(xhrtâ€‹).

Upper Bound Estimator

Theoretical analysis is omitted here.

ReliKApx(xhrt)=12(1rankHS(xhrt)Nâˆ’(h)âˆ£SHâˆ£+1rankTS(xhrt)Nâˆ’(t)âˆ£STâˆ£).ReliK_{Apx}(x_{hrt})=\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{1}{rank_H^S(x_{hrt})\frac{\mathcal N^-(h)}{|S_H|}}+\frac{1}{rank_T^S(x_{hrt})\frac{\mathcal N^-(t)}{|S_T|}}\right).ReliKApxâ€‹(xhrtâ€‹)=21â€‹ââ›â€‹rankHSâ€‹(xhrtâ€‹)âˆ£SHâ€‹âˆ£Nâˆ’(h)â€‹1â€‹+rankTSâ€‹(xhrtâ€‹)âˆ£STâ€‹âˆ£Nâˆ’(t)â€‹1â€‹â ââ€‹.

Pseudo Code

Input: KG K:âŸ¨E,R,FâŸ©\mathcal K:\langle\mathcal E,\mathcal R,\mathcal F\rangleK:âŸ¨E,R,FâŸ©, triple xhrt=(h,r,t)âˆˆFx_{hrt}=(h,r,t)\in\mathcal Fxhrtâ€‹=(h,r,t)âˆˆF, embedding score function s:EÃ—RÃ—Eâ†’Rs:\mathcal E\times\mathcal R\times\mathcal E\to\mathbb Rs:EÃ—RÃ—Eâ†’R, sample size kâˆˆNk\in\mathbb NkâˆˆN

Output: ReliKLB(xhrt)ReliK_{LB}(x_{hrt})ReliKLBâ€‹(xhrtâ€‹) or ReliKApx(xhrt)ReliK_{Apx}(x_{hrt})ReliKApxâ€‹(xhrtâ€‹)

  1. SHâ†S_H\getsSHâ€‹â† sample kkk triples from Nâˆ’(h)\mathcal N^-(h)Nâˆ’(h); STâ†S_T\getsSTâ€‹â† sample kkk triples from Nâˆ’(t)N^-(t)Nâˆ’(t).

  2. rankHâ†1rank_H\gets1rankHâ€‹â†1; rankTâ†1rank_T\gets1rankTâ€‹â†1

  3. for xhâ€²râ€²tâ€²âˆˆSHâˆªSTx_{h'r't'}\in S_H\cup S_Txhâ€²râ€²tâ€²â€‹âˆˆSHâ€‹âˆªSTâ€‹ do

    • If s(xhrt)â‰¤s(xhâ€²râ€²tâ€²)s(x_{hrt})\le s(x_{h'r't'})s(xhrtâ€‹)â‰¤s(xhâ€²râ€²tâ€²â€‹) then

      • if hâ€²=hh'=hhâ€²=h then

        rankHâ†rankH+1rank_H\gets rank_H+1rankHâ€‹â†rankHâ€‹+1

      • if tâ€²=tt'=ttâ€²=t then

        rankTâ†rankT+1rank_T\gets rank_T+1rankTâ€‹â†rankTâ€‹+1

  4. return 12(1rankH+âˆ£Nâˆ’(h)âˆ£âˆ’âˆ£SHâˆ£+1rankT+âˆ£Nâˆ’(t)âˆ£âˆ’âˆ£STâˆ£)\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{1}{rank_H+|\mathcal N^-(h)|-|S_H|}+\frac{1}{rank_T+|\mathcal N^-(t)|-|S_T|}\right)21â€‹(rankHâ€‹+âˆ£Nâˆ’(h)âˆ£âˆ’âˆ£SHâ€‹âˆ£1â€‹+rankTâ€‹+âˆ£Nâˆ’(t)âˆ£âˆ’âˆ£STâ€‹âˆ£1â€‹) for ReliKLBReliK_{LB}ReliKLBâ€‹

    or 12(1rankHNâˆ’(h)âˆ£SHâˆ£+1rankTNâˆ’(t)âˆ£STâˆ£)\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{1}{rank_H\frac{\mathcal N^-(h)}{|S_H|}}+\frac{1}{rank_T\frac{\mathcal N^-(t)}{|S_T|}}\right)21â€‹(rankHâ€‹âˆ£SHâ€‹âˆ£Nâˆ’(h)â€‹1â€‹+rankTâ€‹âˆ£STâ€‹âˆ£Nâˆ’(t)â€‹1â€‹) for ReliKApxReliK_{Apx}ReliKApxâ€‹

Time Complexity

O(k)\mathcal O(k)O(k).

When kâ‰ˆ20%â‹…nk\approx 20\%\cdot nkâ‰ˆ20%â‹…n, 2.5X faster, mean square error = 0.002.

Experimental Evaluation

omitted

entry.title: ç®—æ³•å’Œè®¡ç®—å¤æ‚åº¦ 8 Branching Programs and Barringtonâ€™s Theorem
entry.content:
NC1âŠ†L/polyâŠ†NL/polyâŠ†AC1NC^1\subseteq L/poly\subseteq NL/poly\subseteq AC^1NC1âŠ†L/polyâŠ†NL/polyâŠ†AC1.

The model of branching programs that give a precise characterization of L/polyL/polyL/poly and NL/polyNL/polyNL/poly.

Deterministic / non-deterministic branching program

Boolean Branching Program

Deterministic

ğŸ“–Definition 32. A Deterministic Boolean branching program BBB with nnn inputs consists of the following:

  • A directed acyclic graph D=(V,A)D=(V,A)D=(V,A), where the out-degree of all nodes is in {0,1,2}\{0,1,2\}{0,1,2}.
  • A partial labeling â„“V:Vâ†’{0,1,x1,â‹¯â€‰,xn}\ell_V:V\to\{0,1,x_1,\cdots,x_n\}â„“Vâ€‹:Vâ†’{0,1,x1â€‹,â‹¯,xnâ€‹} of the nodes of DDD.
  • A partial labeling â„“A:Aâ†’{0,1}\ell_A:A\to\{0,1\}â„“Aâ€‹:Aâ†’{0,1} of the edges of DDD.
  • An initial node sâˆˆVs\in VsâˆˆV.

When node vvv is not labeled by â„“V\ell_Vâ„“Vâ€‹, we say that vvv is dummy.

If â„“V(v)âˆˆ{0,1}\ell_V(v)\in\{0,1\}â„“Vâ€‹(v)âˆˆ{0,1}, we say that vvv is an output node.

The graph DDD and the labeling function â„“V,â„“A\ell_V,\ell_Aâ„“Vâ€‹,â„“Aâ€‹ should satisfy:

  1. The node sss is not a dummy node.
  2. If â„“V(v)âˆˆ{x1,â‹¯â€‰,xn}\ell_V(v)\in\{x_1,\cdots,x_n\}â„“Vâ€‹(v)âˆˆ{x1â€‹,â‹¯,xnâ€‹}, the out-degree of vvv is 222, and one outgoing edges of vvv is labeled 000 and 111 by â„“A\ell_Aâ„“Aâ€‹ respectively.
  3. If â„“V(v)âˆˆ{0,1}\ell_V(v)\in\{0,1\}â„“Vâ€‹(v)âˆˆ{0,1}, i.e., vvv is an output node, the out-degree of vvv is 000.
  4. If vvv is a dummy node, the in-degree of vvv is not 000, the out-degree of vvv is 111.

A branching program with nnn inputs compute a Boolean function f:{0,1}nâ†’{0,1}f:\{0,1\}^n\to\{0,1\}f:{0,1}nâ†’{0,1} in a natural way.

Given an input xâˆˆ{0,1}nx\in\{0,1\}^nxâˆˆ{0,1}n, start in the initial node sss, follow a path to an output node, thereby giving the value of f(x)f(x)f(x).

When passing through dummy node, directly go through the unique path.

When passing through labeled node, go to 111-labeled edge if xi=1x_i=1xiâ€‹=1, 000-labeled edge if xi=0x_i=0xiâ€‹=0.

Non-deterministic

Simply modify the deterministic branching program:

  • label of vertices is â„“V:Vâ†’{0,1,âˆ—,x1,â‹¯â€‰,xn}\ell_V:V\to\{0,1,*,x_1,\cdots,x_n\}â„“Vâ€‹:Vâ†’{0,1,âˆ—,x1â€‹,â‹¯,xnâ€‹}. If â„“V(v)=âˆ—\ell_V(v)=*â„“Vâ€‹(v)=âˆ—, vvv is called a choice node.
  • We require the out-degree of vvv is 222 and outgoing edges are not labeled by â„“A\ell_Aâ„“Aâ€‹.

For a given input xâˆˆ{0,1}nx\in\{0,1\}^nxâˆˆ{0,1}n, traverse the branching program from sss, but at a choice node choose to follow an arbitrary arc.

We say that the non-deterministic branching program accepts xxx if there exist such choices leading the path to an output node labeled 111.

ğŸ“–Definition 33. The size of a branching program is the number of nodes in the branching program. The length of a branching program is the length of the longest path from sss to a node to out degree 000.

Then define complexity classes of languages computed by size-bounded branching programs.

ğŸ“–Definition 34. Let S:Nâ†’NS:\mathbb N\to\mathbb NS:Nâ†’N. BPSIZE(S(n))BPSIZE(S(n))BPSIZE(S(n)) is the class of languages computed by families of deterministic Boolean branching program of size O(S(n))O(S(n))O(S(n)). Similarly, NPBSIZE(S(n))NPBSIZE(S(n))NPBSIZE(S(n)) is the class of languages computed by families of non-deterministic Boolean branching program of size O(S(n))O(S(n))O(S(n)).

ğŸ¤”Theorem 43. L/poly=BPSIZE(nO(1)),NL/poly=NBPSIZE(nO(1))L/poly=BPSIZE(n^{O(1)}),NL/poly=NBPSIZE(n^{O(1)})L/poly=BPSIZE(nO(1)),NL/poly=NBPSIZE(nO(1)).

ğŸ¤”Theorem 44. L=ULâˆ’BPSIZE(nO(1)),NL=ULâˆ’NBPSIZE(nO(1))L=U_L-BPSIZE(n^{O(1)}),NL=U_L-NBPSIZE(n^{O(1)})L=ULâ€‹âˆ’BPSIZE(nO(1)),NL=ULâ€‹âˆ’NBPSIZE(nO(1)).

Programs over Monoids and Bounded Width Branching Programs

monoid å«å¹ºåŠç¾¤

What if we restrict the width of branching programs?

Consider the width to be constant.

ğŸ“–Definition 35. A branching program BBB is in layered form, if there is a partition of the nodes of BBB into layers V1,â‹¯â€‰,Vl,V=V1âˆªâ‹¯âˆªVlV_1,\cdots ,V_l,V=V_1\cup\cdots\cup V_lV1â€‹,â‹¯,Vlâ€‹,V=V1â€‹âˆªâ‹¯âˆªVlâ€‹, in such a way that every edge go between some pair of adjacent layers ViV_iViâ€‹ and Vi+1V_{i+1}Vi+1â€‹.

ğŸ“–Definition 36. The width of a branching program with partition into layers V=V1âˆªâ‹¯âˆªVlV=V_1\cup\cdots\cup V_lV=V1â€‹âˆªâ‹¯âˆªVlâ€‹ is the size of the largest layer, maxiâˆ£Viâˆ£max_i|V_i|maxiâ€‹âˆ£Viâ€‹âˆ£.

Then here comes new complexity classes.

ğŸ“–Definition 37. BWBPBWBPBWBP is the class of languages computed by families of Boolean branching programs polynomial size and width O(1)O(1)O(1).

Itâ€™s easy to show AC0âŠ†BWBPAC^0\subseteq BWBPAC0âŠ†BWBP (â“)

Conjecture: MAJâˆˆÌ¸BWBPMAJ\not\in BWBPMAJî€ âˆˆBWBP.

Fact: BWBP=NC1BWBP=NC^1BWBP=NC1.

Consider computation over finite algebraic structures, finite groups.

ğŸ“–Definition 38. A monoid is a set MMM closed under an associative binary operation s.t. MMM has an identity element:

  1. For all x,yâˆˆMx,y\in Mx,yâˆˆM, we have xyâˆˆMxy\in MxyâˆˆM. å°é—­æ€§
  2. For all x,y,zâˆˆMx,y,z\in Mx,y,zâˆˆM, we have x(yz)=(xy)zx(yz)=(xy)zx(yz)=(xy)z. ç»“åˆå¾‹
  3. There is an element 1âˆˆM1\in M1âˆˆM s.t. 1x=x1=x1x=x1=x1x=x1=x for all xâˆˆMx\in MxâˆˆM å«æœ‰å¹ºå…ƒ

The set of functions from a set SSS to itself which forms a monoid, denoted TST_STSâ€‹.

The set of partial functions from a set SSS to itself forms a monoid, denote PTSPT_SPTSâ€‹.

Commonsense: Any group is a monoid.

ğŸ“–Definition 39. Let MMM be a finite monoid. A program PPP over MMM with nnn inputs consists of the following:

  1. A sequence I1,â‹¯â€‰,IlI_1,\cdots,I_lI1â€‹,â‹¯,Ilâ€‹ of triples of the form âŸ¨i,g0,g1âŸ©\langle i,g_0,g_1\rangleâŸ¨i,g0â€‹,g1â€‹âŸ©, where iâˆˆ{1,â‹¯â€‰,n}i\in\{1,\cdots,n\}iâˆˆ{1,â‹¯,n} and g0,g1âˆˆMg_0,g_1\in Mg0â€‹,g1â€‹âˆˆM.
  2. An accepting set AâŠ†MA\subseteq MAâŠ†M.

The triples is called instructions of the program PPP.

A program PPP over MMM with nnn inputs define a Boolean function f:{0,1}nâ†’{0,1}f:\{0,1\}^n\to\{0,1\}f:{0,1}nâ†’{0,1} in a natural way:

  • Let xâˆˆ{0,1}nx\in\{0,1\}^nxâˆˆ{0,1}n.
  • The output of an instruction I=âŸ¨i,g0,g1âŸ©I=\langle i,g_0,g_1\rangleI=âŸ¨i,g0â€‹,g1â€‹âŸ© is given by I(x)=gxiI(x)=g_{x_i}I(x)=gxiâ€‹â€‹.
  • The output of the program is P(x)=âˆj=1lIj(x)P(x)=\prod_{j=1}^lI_j(x)P(x)=âˆj=1lâ€‹Ijâ€‹(x).
  • Finally f(x)=1f(x)=1f(x)=1 iff P(x)âˆˆAP(x)\in AP(x)âˆˆA.

ğŸ“–Definition 40. The length of a program PPP is the number of instructions of PPP.

ğŸ¤”Proposition 10: Let fff be a Boolean function computed by a family of polynomial length programs over a finite monoid MMM. Then fâˆˆNC1f\in NC^1fâˆˆNC1.

ğŸ¤”Proposition 11. BWBPâŠ†NC1BWBP\subseteq NC^1BWBPâŠ†NC1.

Barringtonâ€™s Theorem

Any language in NC1NC^1NC1 can be computed by polynomial size constant width branching programs.

Theorem 45 (Barringtonâ€™s Theorem). BWBP=NC1BWBP=NC^1BWBP=NC1.

By constructing polynomial length programs over group S5S_5S5â€‹ of permutations of 555 elements.

The width is fixed 555.

We denote the identity permutation by eâˆˆS5e\in S_5eâˆˆS5â€‹.

ğŸ“–Definition 41. Let PPP be a program over S5S_5S5â€‹ and let ÏƒâˆˆS5\sigma\in S_5ÏƒâˆˆS5â€‹ be a 555-cycle. We say that PPP Ïƒ\sigmaÏƒ-computes a Boolean function fff if P(x)=ÏƒP(x)=\sigmaP(x)=Ïƒ when f(x)=1f(x)=1f(x)=1 and P(x)=eP(x)=eP(x)=e when f(x)=0f(x)=0f(x)=0. We can also simply say that PPP 555-cycle computes fff.

ğŸ¤”Lemma. Let Ïƒ\sigmaÏƒ and Ï„\tauÏ„ be 555-cycles. If a program PPP over S5S_5S5â€‹ of length lll Ïƒ\sigmaÏƒ-computes fff, then there is another program Pâ€²P'Pâ€² of length lll over S5S_5S5â€‹ that Ï„\tauÏ„-computes fff.

ğŸ¤”Lemma. If a program PPP over S5S_5S5â€‹ of length lll 555-cycle computes fff, then there is another program Pâ€²P'Pâ€² of length lll that 555-cycle computes Â¬f\neg fÂ¬f.

ğŸ“–Definition 42 (commutator äº¤æ¢å­). Let GGG be a group and g,hâˆˆGg,h\in Gg,hâˆˆG. The commutator [g,h][g,h][g,h] is the element gâˆ’1hâˆ’1ghg^{-1}h^{-1}ghgâˆ’1hâˆ’1gh.

ğŸ¤”Lemma. There exists 555-cycles Ïƒ1\sigma_1Ïƒ1â€‹ and Ïƒ2\sigma_2Ïƒ2â€‹ s.t. their commutator [Ïƒ1,Ïƒ2][\sigma_1,\sigma_2][Ïƒ1â€‹,Ïƒ2â€‹], is also a 555-cycle.

Ïƒ1=(1,2,3,4,5),Ïƒ2=(1,3,5,4,2).\sigma_1=(1,2,3,4,5),\sigma_2=(1,3,5,4,2).Ïƒ1â€‹=(1,2,3,4,5),Ïƒ2â€‹=(1,3,5,4,2).

[Ïƒ1,Ïƒ2]=(1,2,5,3,4)[\sigma_1,\sigma_2]=(1,2,5,3,4)[Ïƒ1â€‹,Ïƒ2â€‹]=(1,2,5,3,4)

ğŸ¤”Proposition 12. Let CCC be a fanin 222 circuit of depth ddd. Then there exist a program PPP of length at most 4d4^d4d that 555-cycle computes the output of CCC.

By Proposition 11 and 12, we obtain Barringtonâ€™s Theorem.

å£è¯­è¡¨è¾¾ç»ƒä¹  Mit mÃ¸de med dansk kultur

Jeg oplevede dansk kultur for fÃ¸rste gang, da jeg kom til Danmark for at studere. Jeg har lagt mÃ¦rke til flere forskelle og ligheder mellem Danmark og mit hjemland. For eksempel bruger man i mit hjemland ofte â€˜Deâ€™, nÃ¥r man taler med Ã¦ldre eller folk, man ikke kender godt. I Danmark siger man bare â€˜duâ€™ til alle, og det gÃ¸r, at folk fÃ¸ler sig mere lige. Det synes jeg er meget spÃ¦ndende.

En anden stor forskel er tillid. I Danmark stoler folk meget pÃ¥ hinanden. Man ser ofte, at folk efterlader deres ting udenfor, uden at vÃ¦re bange for, at de bliver stjÃ¥let. I mit hjemland er vi mere forsigtige, fordi vi ikke har samme tillid. Jeg synes, det er godt, at der er sÃ¥ meget tillid her.

Noget andet, jeg har lagt mÃ¦rke til, er mÃ¥den, danskerne kommunikerer pÃ¥. I mit hjemland bruger vi ofte meget kropssprog, mens danskerne er mere rolige. Men de siger, hvad de mener, og det kan vÃ¦re lidt overraskende i starten. Jeg har ogsÃ¥ lÃ¦rt, at lighed er meget vigtigt i Danmark. BÃ¥de mÃ¦nd og kvinder deler husarbejde og bÃ¸rnepasning, hvilket er anderledes fra mit hjemland.

Hygge er ogsÃ¥ noget, der er meget typisk dansk. Det handler om at skabe en hyggelig og afslappet stemning, ofte med venner og familie. I mit hjemland er socialisering mere hÃ¸jlydt og aktiv, sÃ¥ hygge har vÃ¦ret en ny oplevelse for mig. Men jeg kan godt lide det.

Til sidst har jeg lagt mÃ¦rke til, at danskerne ikke altid er sÃ¥ gode til at tale om problemer. De vil hellere undgÃ¥ konflikter, hvilket er noget, jeg har skullet vÃ¦nne mig til. Men jeg synes, det er godt, at danskerne gÃ¥r op i tolerance og respekt for hinanden. Alle bliver behandlet pÃ¥ samme mÃ¥de, og det er noget, jeg virkelig har lÃ¦rt at sÃ¦tte pris pÃ¥.

entry.title: Fair AI/ML 0 Overview
entry.content:
This semester, I will do a project again with Iannis.

I took some time to review the tutorial Fairness in AI/ML via Social Choice by Evi Micha & Nisarg Shah.

Social Choice Theory: Aggregating individual preferences into â€œgoodâ€ collective decisions

Fairness in Social Choice

å¾ˆç†Ÿæ‚‰äº†ï¼Œå¯ä»¥å¿«é€Ÿæ è¿‡ã€‚

âš ï¸è¿™é‡Œè€ƒè™‘çš„æ˜¯ DIVISIBLE ITEMS.

EF, PROP

Fair division: Agents NNN, divisible resources MMM, utility function uiu_iuiâ€‹.

Non-negative utilities (good), non-positive utilities (chores).

Proportionality, envy-freeness.

The Core

A core is a subset of agents, among which they can redistribute their entitlements.

But redistributed entitlements shouldnâ€™t be a Pareto improvement.

2 types of the core

  1. Resource-scaling version

    No group of agents SSS should be able to find any allocation BBB of their proportionally entitled share of the resources that is Pareto improvement.

    âˆƒÌ¸SâŠ†N,âˆ£Sâˆ£âˆ£Nâˆ£â‹…Mâ†’B:ui(Bi)>ui(Ai)âˆ€iâˆˆS\not\exist S\subseteq N,\frac{|S|}{|N|}\cdot M\to B:u_i(B_i)\gt u_i(A_i)\forall i\in Sî€ âˆƒSâŠ†N,âˆ£Nâˆ£âˆ£Sâˆ£â€‹â‹…Mâ†’B:uiâ€‹(Biâ€‹)>uiâ€‹(Aiâ€‹)âˆ€iâˆˆS

  2. Utility-scaling version

    No group of agents SSS should be able to find any allocation BBB of the resources that is a Pareto improvement even after proportional utility-scaling.

    âˆƒÌ¸SâŠ†N,Mâ†’B:âˆ£Sâˆ£âˆ£Nâˆ£â‹…ui(Bi)>ui(Ai)âˆ€iâˆˆS\not\exist S\subseteq N,M\to B:\frac{|S|}{|N|}\cdot u_i(B_i)\gt u_i(A_i)\forall i\in Sî€ âˆƒSâŠ†N,Mâ†’B:âˆ£Nâˆ£âˆ£Sâˆ£â€‹â‹…uiâ€‹(Biâ€‹)>uiâ€‹(Aiâ€‹)âˆ€iâˆˆS

  • Two versions are equivalent for some setting.
  • They are different when utilities are not linear additive.
  • If there is no scalable resource, there is no way to define resource-scaling version. But it is more appealing.

Nash Social Welfare

NSW is geometric mean of agent utilities.

NSW(A)=(âˆiâˆˆNui(Ai))1/âˆ£Nâˆ£NSW(A)=\left(\prod_{i\in N}u_i(A_i)\right)^{1/|N|}NSW(A)=(iâˆˆNâˆâ€‹uiâ€‹(Aiâ€‹))1/âˆ£Nâˆ£

There are some other welfare functions:

  • Utilitarian social welfare: USW(A)=1âˆ£Nâˆ£â‹…âˆ‘iâˆˆNui(Ai)USW(A)=\frac{1}{|N|}\cdot\sum_{i\in N}u_i(A_i)USW(A)=âˆ£Nâˆ£1â€‹â‹…âˆ‘iâˆˆNâ€‹uiâ€‹(Aiâ€‹)

    ä¸ºä»€ä¹ˆè¦èµ·è¿™ä¹ˆæ€ªçš„åå­—ï¼Œå« average social welfare ä¸å¥½å˜›ï¼

  • Egalitarian social welfare: ESW(A)=minâ¡iâˆˆNui(Ai)ESW(A)=\min_{i\in N}u_i(A_i)ESW(A)=miniâˆˆNâ€‹uiâ€‹(Aiâ€‹)

    æ˜æ˜å¯ä»¥å« least social welfare çš„â€¦â€¦

ğŸ¤”Theorem [Varian '74]: Any allocation maximizing NSW is envy-free in the core.

ğŸ¤”Theorem [Orlin '10]: An allocation maximizing the NSW can be computed in strongly polynomial time.

Application of Core: Committee Selection

There are set of voters NNN, set of candidates MMM.

Each agent iii approves a subset of candidates AiâŠ†MA_i\subseteq MAiâ€‹âŠ†M.

  • The utility for each voter is defined as the number of intersection of committee member and its approval.

    ui(W)=âˆ£Wâˆ©Aiâˆ£u_i(W)=|W\cap A_i|uiâ€‹(W)=âˆ£Wâˆ©Aiâ€‹âˆ£

  • The goal is to find WâŠ†MW\subseteq MWâŠ†M with âˆ£Wâˆ£â‰¤k|W|\le kâˆ£Wâˆ£â‰¤k with given kkk.

WWW is in the core if there is no SâŠ†NS\subseteq NSâŠ†N and TâŠ†MT\subseteq MTâŠ†M with âˆ£Tâˆ£â‰¤âˆ£Sâˆ£âˆ£Nâˆ£â‹…k|T|\le\frac{|S|}{|N|}\cdot kâˆ£Tâˆ£â‰¤âˆ£Nâˆ£âˆ£Sâˆ£â€‹â‹…k (Here the candidates are resources, so its resource-scaling version) s.t. ui(T)>ui(W)âˆ€iâˆˆSu_i(T)\gt u_i(W)\forall i\in Suiâ€‹(T)>uiâ€‹(W)âˆ€iâˆˆS.

Advantages

Itâ€™s broadly defined

  • It often depends only on the definition of AGENTS and PREFERENCES.
  • Applicable to any setting as long as you define these two pieces of information.

Notions such as the core achieve group fairness to all possible groups.

  • No need to pre-specify the groups.
  • scale automatically with group size and cohesiveness, without additional parameters.

Envy-Freeness in ML

Classification

The model

  • Population of individuals given by a distribution DDD over XXX.

    individual iii represent data point xiâˆˆXx_i\in Xxiâ€‹âˆˆX.

  • Classifier f:Xâ†’Yf:X\to Yf:Xâ†’Y maps every individual to a classification outcome

Types of classification:

  • Hard binary
  • Hard multi-class
  • Soft binary
  • Soft multi-class

Objective: minimize loss function

Utility function should be somehow related to loss function.

How to measure fairness in ML?

Individual Fairness

[Dwork, Hardt, Pitassi, Reingold, Zemel, 2012]

Similar individuals should be treated similarly

Classifier fff is individual fair if

âˆ€x,yâˆˆN,D(f(x),f(y))â‰¤d(x,y)\forall x,y\in N,D(f(x),f(y))\le d(x,y)âˆ€x,yâˆˆN,D(f(x),f(y))â‰¤d(x,y)

Envy-Freeness

[Balcan, Dick, Noothigattu, Procaccia, 2019]

Equal individuals shouldnâ€™t envy each other.

Classifier fff is envy-free if

âˆ€x,yâˆˆN,ux(f(x))â‰¥ux(f(y))\forall x,y\in N,u_x(f(x))\ge u_x(f(y))âˆ€x,yâˆˆN,uxâ€‹(f(x))â‰¥uxâ€‹(f(y))

Envy-freeness is too strong for deterministic classifiers

  • loss of optimal deterministic EF classifier â‰¥1\ge1â‰¥1.
  • Loss of optimal randomized EF classifier â‰¤1/Î³\le1/\gammaâ‰¤1/Î³.

Preference-Informed IF

[Kim, Korolova, Rothblum, Yona, 2019]

Similar individuals shouldnâ€™t envy each other too much.

Classifier is PIIF if

\forall x,y\in N,\exist z\in Y,D(z,f(y))\le d(x,y)\and u_x(f(x))\ge u_x(z).

Approximate EF

Equal individuals shouldnâ€™t envy each other too much.

Classifier fff is approximately EF if âˆ€x,yâˆˆN,ux(f(x))â‰¥ux(f(y))âˆ’Ïµ\forall x,y\in N,u_x(f(x))\ge u_x(f(y))-\epsilonâˆ€x,yâˆˆN,uxâ€‹(f(x))â‰¥uxâ€‹(f(y))âˆ’Ïµ.

OR

Classifier fff is approximately EF if âˆ€x,yâˆˆN,ux(f(x))â‰¥ux(f(y))âˆ’d(x,y)\forall x,y\in N,u_x(f(x))\ge u_x(f(y))-d(x,y)âˆ€x,yâˆˆN,uxâ€‹(f(x))â‰¥uxâ€‹(f(y))âˆ’d(x,y)

Average Group Envy-Freeness

Equal groups shouldnâ€™t envy-each other too much on average.

Classifier fff is approximately average group EF w.r.t. groups G1,G2G_1,G_2G1â€‹,G2â€‹ if

Exâˆ¼G1,yâˆ¼G2[ux(f(y))âˆ’ux(f(x))]â‰¤0\mathbb E_{x\sim G_1,y\sim G_2}[u_x(f(y))-u_x(f(x))]\le 0Exâˆ¼G1â€‹,yâˆ¼G2â€‹â€‹[uxâ€‹(f(y))âˆ’uxâ€‹(f(x))]â‰¤0

Applicable for decision-making with limited resources

  • e.g. deciding on loan or bail applications

Clustering

In ML

Goal: Analyze datasets to summarize their characteristics

Objects in the same group are similar

In Economics

Goal: Allocate a set of facilities that serve a set of agents. (e.g. hospital)

Some Objective Functions

kkk-median: minimizes the sum of the distances

kkk-means: minimizes the sum of the square of the distances

kkk-center: minimizes the maximum distance

    â€œIf a group can afford TTT, then TTT should not be a strict Pareto improvement for the groupâ€

ğŸ¤”Theorem. There exists an algorithm Greedy Capture that returns a clustering solution in the (1+2)(1+\sqrt2)(1+2â€‹)-core under any metric space. For arbitrary metric spaces and Î±<2\alpha\lt 2Î±<2, a clustering solution in the Î±\alphaÎ±-core is not guaranteed to exist.

ğŸ¤”Theorem.

  • For L2L_2L2â€‹, Greedy Capture returns a solution in the 222-core
  • For L1L_1L1â€‹ and LâˆL_\inftyLâˆâ€‹, GC does not always return a (<1+2)(\lt1+\sqrt2)(<1+2â€‹)-core
  • For L2L_2L2â€‹ and Î±<1.154\alpha<1.154Î±<1.154, a clustering solution in the Î±\alphaÎ±-core is not guaranteed to exist
  • For L1L_1L1â€‹ and LâˆL_\inftyLâˆâ€‹, and Î±<1.4\alpha\lt1.4Î±<1.4, a clustering solution in the Î±\alphaÎ±-core is not guaranteed to exist

Core in Non-Centroid Clustering

Non-Centroid Clustering

  • Partition the individuals into kkk clusters
  • loss for each cluster: for SâŠ†NS\subseteq NSâŠ†N and iâˆˆS,â„“i(S)â‰¥0i\in S,\ell_i(S)\ge0iâˆˆS,â„“iâ€‹(S)â‰¥0.

Î±\alphaÎ±-core: A solution CCC is in the Î±\alphaÎ±-core with Î±â‰¥1\alpha\ge1Î±â‰¥1, if there is no group of points SâŠ†NS\subseteq NSâŠ†N with âˆ£Sâˆ£â‰¥n/k|S|\ge n/kâˆ£Sâˆ£â‰¥n/k s.t.

âˆ€iâˆˆS,â„“i(S)<â„“i(C(i))\forall i\in S,\ell_i(S)\lt\ell_i(C(i))âˆ€iâˆˆS,â„“iâ€‹(S)<â„“iâ€‹(C(i))

Average loss: for each SâŠ†N,â„“i(S)=1âˆ£Sâˆ£âˆ‘iâ€²âˆˆSd(i,iâ€²)S\subseteq N,\ell_i(S)=\frac{1}{|S|}\sum_{i'\in S}d(i,i')SâŠ†N,â„“iâ€‹(S)=âˆ£Sâˆ£1â€‹âˆ‘iâ€²âˆˆSâ€‹d(i,iâ€²)

ğŸ¤”Theorem

  • Greedy Capture returns a clustering solution in the (n/k)(n/k)(n/k)-core under any metric space
  • For arbitrary metric space and Î±<1.366\alpha\lt1.366Î±<1.366, a clustering solution in the Î±\alphaÎ±-core is not guaranteed to exist

Open question: Does a clustering solution in the O(1)O(1)O(1)-core always exist?

entry.title: ç®—æ³•å’Œè®¡ç®—å¤æ‚åº¦ 7 Bounded Depth Boolean Circuits
entry.content:
What if Boolean circuits has bounded depth?

Depth of Boolean circuit: the length of a longest path from an input gate to an output gate.

Itâ€™s a model of parallel computation where depth corresponds to parallel time.

Parallel model of random access machine PRAM ç—›è‹¦çš„è®¡ç®—å‡ ä½•è¯¾çš„å›å¿†

ğŸ“–Definition of SIZEâˆ’DEPTHSIZE-DEPTHSIZEâˆ’DEPTH. Let S:Nâ†’NS:\mathbb N\to\mathbb NS:Nâ†’N and d:Nâ†’Nd:\mathbb N\to\mathbb Nd:Nâ†’N. SIZEâˆ’DEPTH(S(n),d(n))SIZE-DEPTH(S(n),d(n))SIZEâˆ’DEPTH(S(n),d(n)) is the class of languages computed by families of Boolean circuits of size O(S(n))O(S(n))O(S(n)) and depth O(d(n))O(d(n))O(d(n)).

ğŸ“–Definition of NCiNC^iNCi. For iâ‰¥0i\ge0iâ‰¥0, define NCi=SIZEâˆ’DEPTH(nO(1),logâ¡i(n))NC^i=SIZE-DEPTH(n^{O(1)},\log^i(n))NCi=SIZEâˆ’DEPTH(nO(1),logi(n)), and further define NC=âˆªiâ‰¥1NCiNC=\cup_{i\ge1}NC^iNC=âˆªiâ‰¥1â€‹NCi.

These circuit classes is restrict to polynomial size and poly-logarithmic depth.

By definition, NCâŠ†P/polyNC\subseteq P/polyNCâŠ†P/poly, hence ULâˆ’NCâŠ†PU_L-NC\subseteq PULâ€‹âˆ’NCâŠ†P.

ä¸ºä»€ä¹ˆå‘¢ï¼Ÿå›é¡¾å®šä¹‰ P/poly=â‹ƒk>0SIZE(nk)P/poly=\bigcup_{k\gt0}SIZE(n^k)P/poly=â‹ƒk>0â€‹SIZE(nk)ï¼Œå‘ç°å®ƒçš„å¤šäº†ä¸€ä¸ªæ·±åº¦çš„é™åˆ¶ã€‚

In fact PâŠ†Ì¸NCP\not\subseteq NCPî€ âŠ†NC is expected to hold. This means not all languages in PPP can benefit greatly from parallelism.

General Boolean Circuits

Consider Boolean circuits that allows arbitrary fanin gate and more general functions than AND,OR,NOTAND, OR, NOTAND,OR,NOT.

General definition of Boolean circuit. A Boolean circuit CCC with nnn inputs and mmm outputs consists of the following:

  • An underlying directed acyclic graph D=(V,A)D=(V,A)D=(V,A) (multiple arcs is allowed)
  • A labeling â„“\ellâ„“ of the nodes of VVV.
  • A linear ordering on the arcs AAA of VVV.
  • A choice of mmm output gates o1,â‹¯â€‰,omâˆˆVo_1,\cdots,o_m\in Vo1â€‹,â‹¯,omâ€‹âˆˆV

The size of CCC is the number of wires. The labelling function â„“\ellâ„“ should satisfy the following for all gates ggg:

  • If the fanin of ggg is 000, then â„“(g)âˆˆ{0,1,x1,â‹¯â€‰,xn,x1â€¾,â‹¯â€‰,xnâ€¾}\ell(g)\in\{0,1,x_1,\cdots,x_n,\overline{x_1},\cdots,\overline{x_n}\}â„“(g)âˆˆ{0,1,x1â€‹,â‹¯,xnâ€‹,x1â€‹â€‹,â‹¯,xnâ€‹â€‹}.
  • If the fanin of ggg is kâ‰¥1k\ge1kâ‰¥1, then â„“(g)=fg\ell(g)=f_gâ„“(g)=fgâ€‹ where fg:{0,1}kâ†’{0,1}f_g:\{0,1\}^k\to\{0,1\}fgâ€‹:{0,1}kâ†’{0,1} is an kkk-ary Boolean function.

CCC compute a Boolean function f:{0,1}nâ†’{0,1}mf:\{0,1\}^n\to\{0,1\}^mf:{0,1}nâ†’{0,1}m in a natural way.

Boolean functions with k-ary

AND(z_1,\cdots,z_k)=z_1\and\cdots\and z_k\\OR(z_1,\cdots,z_k)=z_1\or\cdots\or z_k\\MOD_m(z_1,\cdots,z_k)=\begin{cases}1\ if\ \sum_{i=1}^kz_i\not\equiv0\mod m\\0\ if\ \sum_{i=1}^kz_i\equiv0\mod m\end{cases}

MOD2MOD_2MOD2â€‹ is the same as the xor-sum.

The major voting function MAJMAJMAJ:

MAJ(z1,â‹¯â€‰,zk)={1Â ifÂ âˆ‘i=1kziâ‰¥k20Â ifÂ âˆ‘i=1kzi<k2MAJ(z_1,\cdots,z_k)=\begin{cases}1\ if\ \sum_{i=1}^kz_i\ge\frac{k}{2}\\0\ if\ \sum_{i=1}^kz_i\lt\frac{k}{2}\end{cases}MAJ(z1â€‹,â‹¯,zkâ€‹)={1Â ifÂ âˆ‘i=1kâ€‹ziâ€‹â‰¥2kâ€‹0Â ifÂ âˆ‘i=1kâ€‹ziâ€‹<2kâ€‹â€‹

Let w=(w1,â‹¯â€‰,wk)âˆˆRkw=(w_1,\cdots,w_k)\in\mathbb R^kw=(w1â€‹,â‹¯,wkâ€‹)âˆˆRk be weights and tâˆˆRt\in\mathbb RtâˆˆR be a threshold. Then THRw,tTHR_{w,t}THRw,tâ€‹ is defined:

THRw,t(z1,â‹¯â€‰,zk)={1Â ifÂ âˆ‘i=1kwiziâ‰¥t0Â ifÂ âˆ‘i=1kwizi<tTHR_{w,t}(z_1,\cdots,z_k)=\begin{cases}1\ if\ \sum_{i=1}^kw_iz_i\ge t\\0\ if\ \sum_{i=1}^kw_iz_i\lt t\end{cases}THRw,tâ€‹(z1â€‹,â‹¯,zkâ€‹)={1Â ifÂ âˆ‘i=1kâ€‹wiâ€‹ziâ€‹â‰¥t0Â ifÂ âˆ‘i=1kâ€‹wiâ€‹ziâ€‹<tâ€‹

When all weights is 111,

Tt(z1,â‹¯â€‰,zk)={1Â ifÂ âˆ‘i=1kziâ‰¥t0Â ifÂ âˆ‘i=1kzi<tT_t(z_1,\cdots,z_k)=\begin{cases}1\ if\ \sum_{i=1}^kz_i\ge t\\0\ if\ \sum_{i=1}^kz_i\lt t\end{cases}Ttâ€‹(z1â€‹,â‹¯,zkâ€‹)={1Â ifÂ âˆ‘i=1kâ€‹ziâ€‹â‰¥t0Â ifÂ âˆ‘i=1kâ€‹ziâ€‹<tâ€‹

Several Circuit Classes

ğŸ“–Definition of ACiAC^iACi. For iâ‰¥0i\ge0iâ‰¥0, ACiAC^iACi is the class of languages computed by families of Boolean circuits of polynomial size and depth O(logâ¡in)O(\log^in)O(login) using unbounded fanin ANDANDAND and OROROR gates.

ACiAC^iACi is similar to NCiNC^iNCi.

ğŸ¤”Proposition 5. Hierarchy relation between NCNCNC and ACACAC. NCiâŠ†ACiâŠ†NCi+1NC^i\subseteq AC^i\subseteq NC^{i+1}NCiâŠ†ACiâŠ†NCi+1 for all iâ‰¥0i\ge0iâ‰¥0.

NCiâŠ†ACiNC^i\subseteq AC^iNCiâŠ†ACi is obtained by definition.

For ACiâŠ†NCi+1AC^i\subseteq NC^{i+1}ACiâŠ†NCi+1: ANDANDAND and OROROR gates of fanin kkk can be replaced by a binary tree of depth âŒˆlogâ¡2kâŒ‰\lceil\log_2k\rceilâŒˆlog2â€‹kâŒ‰ of corresponding fanin 222 gates. Thus the depth increases by a factor O(logâ¡n)O(\log n)O(logn).

ğŸ“–Definition of AC0,ACC0AC^0,ACC^0AC0,ACC0. Let m>1m\gt1m>1. AC0[m]AC^0[m]AC0[m] is the class of languages computed by families of Boolean circuits of polynomial size and depth O(1)O(1)O(1) using unbounded fanin AND,OR,MODmAND,OR,MOD_mAND,OR,MODmâ€‹ gates. Define ACC0=â‹ƒm>1AC0[m]ACC^0=\bigcup_{m\gt1}AC^0[m]ACC0=â‹ƒm>1â€‹AC0[m].

ğŸ“–Definition of TC0TC^0TC0. TC0TC^0TC0 is the class of languages computed by families of Boolean circuits of polynomial size and depth O(1)O(1)O(1) using unbounded fanin MAJMAJMAJ gates only.

è¯­è¨€ç±» TC0TC^0TC0 å¯ä»¥è¢«çœ‹åšç¥ç»ç½‘ç»œã€‚

Logarithmic Space and Logarithmic Depth Circuits

log-space can be roughly the same as log-depth circuits.

ğŸ¯Theorem 38. ULâˆ’NC1âŠ†LU_L-NC^1\subseteq LULâ€‹âˆ’NC1âŠ†L.

Circuit CCC with depth (logâ¡n)(\log n)(logn) is computable by a O(logâ¡n)O(\log n)O(logn) space Turing Machine.

ğŸ“–Definition of Boolean product of matrices. A=(aij)âˆˆ{0,1}mÃ—r,B=(bij)âˆˆ{0,1}rÃ—nA=(a_{ij})\in\{0,1\}^{m\times r},B=(b_{ij})\in\{0,1\}^{r\times n}A=(aijâ€‹)âˆˆ{0,1}mÃ—r,B=(bijâ€‹)âˆˆ{0,1}rÃ—n. The Boolean product ABABAB is the mÃ—nm\times nmÃ—n Boolean matrix C=(cij)C=(c_{ij})C=(cijâ€‹) s.t.

c_{ij}=\bigvee_{k=1}^ra_{ik}\and a_{kj}.

A nÃ—nn\times nnÃ—n Boolean matrix corresponds to a directed graph. The transitive closure of the graph gives rise to the transitive closure of the matrix.

å›æƒ³èµ·å¤§äºŒå­¦çš„ç¦»æ•£æ•°å­¦äº†å—ï¼Ÿé‚»æ¥çŸ©é˜µçš„é—­åŒ…ä¸å¯è¾¾æ€§ã€‚

ğŸ“–Definition of transitive closure. Transitive closure Aâˆ—A^*Aâˆ— of AAA is the nÃ—nn\times nnÃ—n Boolean matrix given by Aâˆ—=â‹iâ‰¥0AiA^*=\bigvee_{i\ge0}A^iAâˆ—=â‹iâ‰¥0â€‹Ai, where A0A^0A0 is the identity matrix III.

ğŸ¯Theorem 39. NLâŠ†ULâˆ’AC1NL\subseteq U_L-AC^1NLâŠ†ULâ€‹âˆ’AC1

æ‡’å¾—çœ‹è¯æ˜äº†ï¼Œåˆ°å­¦çš„æ—¶å€™å†æ¥

ğŸ¤”Corollary 6. ULâˆ’NC1âŠ†LâŠ†NLâŠ†ULâˆ’AC1U_L-NC^1\subseteq L\subseteq NL\subseteq U_L-AC^1ULâ€‹âˆ’NC1âŠ†LâŠ†NLâŠ†ULâ€‹âˆ’AC1.

å…¶å®è¿™é‡Œä¹Ÿå­˜åœ¨å±‚æ¬¡ç»“æ„ï¼šNLâŠ†ULâˆ’AC1âŠ†ULâˆ’NC2âŠ†L2(=DSPACE(logâ¡2n))NL\subseteq U_L-AC^1\subseteq U_L-NC^2\subseteq L^2(=DSPACE(\log^2n))NLâŠ†ULâ€‹âˆ’AC1âŠ†ULâ€‹âˆ’NC2âŠ†L2(=DSPACE(log2n)).

Functions and Reductions

Boolean circuit is fixed number of inputs, we consider output is also a bounded function of the length of input.

ğŸ“–Definition of length-respecting. A function f:{0,1}âˆ—â†’{0,1}âˆ—f:\{0,1\}^*\to\{0,1\}^*f:{0,1}âˆ—â†’{0,1}âˆ— is length-respecting if for all x,yâˆˆ{0,1}âˆ—x,y\in\{0,1\}^*x,yâˆˆ{0,1}âˆ—, we have âˆ£xâˆ£=âˆ£yâˆ£â‡’âˆ£f(x)âˆ£=âˆ£f(y)âˆ£|x|=|y|\Rarr|f(x)|=|f(y)|âˆ£xâˆ£=âˆ£yâˆ£â‡’âˆ£f(x)âˆ£=âˆ£f(y)âˆ£.

ğŸ“–Definition of AC0AC^0AC0 Turing reduction. Let fff and ggg be length-respecting Boolean functions. We say fff reduces to ggg by an AC0AC^0AC0 Turing reduction if fff is computed by a family of Boolean functions of polynomial size and depth O(1)O(1)O(1) using unbounded fanin ANDANDAND and OROROR gates as well as gates computing any coordinate function of ggg.

ä»€ä¹ˆç©æ„å•Šï¼Œç»•æ¥ç»•å»çš„

If fff reduces to ggg by an AC0AC^0AC0 Turing reduction, it is denoted by fâ‰¤TAC0gf\le_T^{AC^0}gfâ‰¤TAC0â€‹g.

Easy to see that AC0AC^0AC0 Turing reductions satisfy transitivity.

ğŸ¤”Lemma 8. If fâ‰¤TAC0gf\le_T^{AC^0}gfâ‰¤TAC0â€‹g and gâ‰¤TAC0hg\le_T^{AC^0}hgâ‰¤TAC0â€‹h, then fâ‰¤TAC0hf\le_T^{AC^0}hfâ‰¤TAC0â€‹h.

Addition and Multiplication

ADDADDADD: given nnn-bit numbers xxx and yyy, output n+1n+1n+1-bit number zzz s.t. z=x+yz=x+yz=x+y.

MULTMULTMULT: given nnn-bit numbers xxx and yyy, output 2n2n2n-bit number zzz s.t. z=xyz=xyz=xy.

ğŸ¯Theorem 40. ADDâˆˆAC0ADD\in AC^0ADDâˆˆAC0.

!!!

A generalization of ADDADDADD: iterated addition of nnn numbers each of nnn bits.

ITADDITADDITADD: given nnn numbers x1,â‹¯â€‰,xnx^1,\cdots,x^nx1,â‹¯,xn of nnn bits each, output n+âŒˆlogâ¡2nâŒ‰n+\lceil\log_2n\rceiln+âŒˆlog2â€‹nâŒ‰-bit number zzz s.t. z=x1+â‹¯+xnz=x^1+\cdots+x^nz=x1+â‹¯+xn.

ğŸ¯Theorem 41. ITADDâˆˆNC1ITADD\in NC^1ITADDâˆˆNC1.

We can to reduce the task to the task of add 222 numbers each of n+O(logâ¡n)n+O(\log n)n+O(logn) bits. These may be added in depth O(logâ¡n)O(\log n)O(logn) by converting AC0AC^0AC0 for ADDADDADD to a NC1NC^1NC1 circuit.

ğŸ¤”Corollary 7. TC0âŠ†NC1TC^0\subseteq NC^1TC0âŠ†NC1.

Note that MAJâ‰¤TAC0ITADDMAJ\le_T^{AC^0}ITADDMAJâ‰¤TAC0â€‹ITADD by computing the sum of the input bits and comparing to the threshold value.

ğŸ¤”Proposition 6. MULTâ‰¤TAC0ITADDMULT\le_T^{AC^0}ITADDMULTâ‰¤TAC0â€‹ITADD.

Given nnn-bit numbers xxx and yyy, we form the nnn numbers ziz^izi, each of 2nâˆ’12n-12nâˆ’1 bits by letting zi=xi2iyz^i=x_i2^iyzi=xiâ€‹2iy for 0â‰¤i<n0\le i\lt n0â‰¤i<n. Then the product is simply the sum of the numbers z0,â‹¯â€‰,znâˆ’1z^0,\cdots,z^{n-1}z0,â‹¯,znâˆ’1.

BCOUNTBCOUNTBCOUNT: given nnn-bit number xxx, output âŒˆlogâ¡2n+1âŒ‰\lceil\log_2^n+1\rceilâŒˆlog2nâ€‹+1âŒ‰-bit number zzz, the sum of each bit.

Clearly BCOUNTâ‰¤TAC0ITADDBCOUNT\le_T^{AC^0}ITADDBCOUNTâ‰¤TAC0â€‹ITADD.
